DOC.HEAD: First Journalist is Launched Into Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with details, background; picks up 10th graf, `The flight ...
DOC.TEXT: A sleek rocket thundered into the sky over the Central Asian desert Sunday in a joint Soviet-Japanese mission that carried the first journalist into space. Smoke and tongues of flame engulfed the launch pad as the 150-foot rocket lifted off at 1:13 p.m. (3:13 a.m. EST), hurling the Soyuz TM-11 capsule and its crew toward a rendezvous with the Soviet space station Mir. Toyohiro Akiyama, the first journalist and first Japanese in space, joined the mission led by Soviet Cmdr. Viktor Afanasyev and flight engineer Musa Manarov. Japan's TBS television company paid the Soviets $12 million to send Akiyama, a news director for the network, into space. They took out $2.2 million in insurance on his life. ``All conditions normal,'' said an announcer who gave reports every 10 seconds as the rocket soared into orbit in a flawless launch. Akiyama was to describe the trip in live radio and television broadcasts to Tokyo, and conduct sleep studies and experiments to see how Japanese tree frogs cope in a gravity-free environment. Hundreds of foreign journalists watched the launch at the once-secret Baikonur Cosmodrome, 1,250 miles east of Moscow. The space venture by TBS, Japan's biggest private television company, is a watershed for the two countries, which never formally ended their World War II hostilities and still dispute ownership of some islands off the Japanese coast. ``If we continue our friendship, it would be good,'' cosmonaut Afanasyev said at a news conference Saturday. Afanasyev and Manarov will replace two Soviet cosmonauts who have been in the space station for the past four months. Afanasyev and Manarov are expected to stay in space for six months. The eight-day mission was the eighth to hook up with the Mir space station since it was put into orbit in 1986. Fourteen foreign astronauts have ridden into space aboard Soyuz capsules, but Akiyama is the first paying non-scientific passenger. The flight also will boost the Soviet Union's two-year effort to commercialize its space program. ``The Soviets need money,'' Akiyama said. ``Their space industry has to be competitive, like the French, Chinese and Americans have started to do. It's quite natural for the Russians to start this kind of business.'' ``If I work hard and I'm successful, then I expect to get a bonus,'' joked Akiyama, TBS' former bureau chief in Washington. ``If I get space sickness, then it should be counted as sick leave.'' The journalist was carrying three amulets into space, given to him by his father, the prime minister of Japan and by the president of TBS. Asked before launch what he was looking forward to most upon his return in eight days, Akiyama replied: ``I can't wait to have a smoke.'' More than 120 TBS reporters, cameramen and technicians were brought to the cosmodrome to document the flight. Soviet officials went out of their way to open to display the cosmodrome's huge installations for assembling rockets. Foreigners have been subject to a not-so-subtle sales pitch. ``We can launch any satellite from any country ... just bring it here,'' said Major Gen. Alexei Shumilin, deputy director of testing at the cosmodrome.

DOC.HEAD: Much-Delayed Astronomical Mission Under Way
DOC.TEXT: Columbia shot spectacularly through a moonlit sky early Sunday, carrying seven astronauts and an astronomical laboratory into space and helping the nation's space shuttle program end a frustrating year on an upswing. ``It's like an early Christmas present,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. ``It sure goes a long way to erase the disappointments that we had this summer.'' A Soviet Soyuz rocket carrying two cosmonauts and a Japanese television journalist was launched 84 minutes later, bringing to 12 the number of people in space, the most ever at one time. Two cosmonauts are on the space station Mir. The Columbia crew hopes to contact the Soviet crew via ham radio. Columbia had been grounded since May by hydrogen leaks, and the shuttle Atlantis was also delayed by leaks. The launch at 1:49 a.m. EST came on the fifth attempt to put Columbia and its astronomy lab in space for a 10-day mission. ``It was spectacular to watch it go up,'' said Arthur Davidson of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator of one of the Astro observatory's ultraviolet telescopes. ``We're getting a whole new look at the universe.'' The 100-ton spaceship flooded the sky with light visible for hundreds of miles as it thundered toward a 218-mile-high orbit. The launch was delayed 21 minutes when the Air Force, which has responsibility for range safety, sent a helicopter into a layer of clouds to confirm that visibility was sufficient. The unusual helicopter check surprised NASA officials, but Air Force Col. John Wormington said afterward that it saved the launch from being postponed. The moon shining through the clouds over the Florida coast was brightened by the shuttle's 700-foot pillar of flames. ``We really had a light show coming up. That was really something,'' said Columbia's commander Vance Brand, at age 59 the oldest person to reach space. It was NASA's sixth shuttle flight this year, three fewer than planned because of the hydrogen leaks that grounded Columbia and Atlantis through summer and early fall. Atlantis returned from a secret military flight less than two weeks ago. Astronomers have been waiting anxiously to send up the $150 million observatory since the mission's original launch date in 1986. The mission was delayed until this year by the Challenger accident. As Columbia orbits high above Earth's distorting atmosphere, four astronomers on board will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes round-the-clock. An X-ray telescope will be managed by computer commands sent from the ground. The observatory will remain anchored in Columbia's cargo bay throughout the flight and return to Earth with the shuttle. Scientists expect to be surprised by many of Astro's findings since ultraviolet light and X-rays are invisible from Earth. About 240 objects will be studied, including Jupiter, quasars, binary stars, a supernova and Comet Levy, which is on its way out of the solar system. Columbia's other crew members are pilot Guy Gardner, mission secialist Mike Lounge and astronomers Ron Parise, Jeffrey Hoffman, Robert Parker and Sam Durrance.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Palestinian After Four Israelis Stabbed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Yaacov Rad ..' to CORRECT name to Raz and give full title; picks up 14th graf pvs, `The blue-and-white...
DOC.TEXT: Three Palestinians boarded a bus outside Tel Aviv on Sunday and stabbed four Israelis, one of them fatally, police said. A policeman then shot to death one of the attackers and the others were captured. Shouting ``Allahu Akbar!'' (God is Great), the Palestinians rose from their seats and began slashing with knives as the bus passed through a shopping district between the suburban cities of Bnei Brak and Ramat Gan, said Tel Aviv police spokeswoman Etti Greenberg. In a leaflet issued over the weekend, leaders of the three-year Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories had declared Sunday a ``day of escalation'' against Israel. The Palestinians had boarded the bus headed for Tel Aviv at about 9:30 a.m. (2:30 a.m. EST), Greenberg said. When the knifing began, the driver stopped and pulled a pistol out, and the passengers fled the bus, she said. A paramilitary border policeman driving behind the bus then climbed aboard and opened fire with an Uzi submachine on one of the assailants, killing him. Greenberg said two of the assailants were injured but she did not know how. Israel army radio said one was shot in the hand, and the other was beaten by angry Israelis. The four injured Israelis were taken by taxi to Beilinson Hospital, where one of the victims, a 24-year-old man, died of stab wounds to the heart and lungs. A man who was crossing the street when he saw the attack said on army radio: ``I saw a big commotion on the bus, as though everyone was beating each other up.'' ``Then people came out, they were all bloodied. Some looked very seriously injured, we stopped a taxi and put them in, there was a man dripping blood from his mouth,'' said the witness, whose name was not given. Passenger Ilana Bardash said she had gotten on the bus outside her bank and shortly afterward, ``I heard the shouts of Allahu Akbar.'' ``I saw three people were injured. The door was stuck. We just pushed it open and ran outside, and just started shouting for police,'' Mrs. Bardash said. Yaacov Raz, commander of police in the Tel Aviv area, praised the driver for his ``good, speedy action'' in taking control of the bus and preventing more stabbings. The blue-and-white bus was taken to the Ramat Gan police station with the dead attacker lying in the aisle. His stockinged, shoeless foot stuck out from under a sheet into abandoned shopping bags and pools of blood. On Saturday, an Arab woman was shot dead in Jerusalem as she tried to stab a police officer, who was unharmed because he wore a flak jacket. Also Saturday, a grenade was thrown in a shopping area in central Tel Aviv. The explosion caused no injuries, Israeli reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Warns Soviets Not to Send Troops to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Sunday warned the Soviet Union that it could lose its influence in the Arabs world if it sent troops to the Persian Gulf, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduward Shevardnadze said Thursday that Moscow would send troops if Soviets trapped in Iraq were mistreated. The Soviets previously had said they wouldn't participate in the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Saddam Hussein. An Iraqi Foreign Ministry spokesman charged that Shevardnadze ``seems to be looking for a pretext to send troops to the region.'' Shevardnadze, speaking at the United Nations, declared that ``everyone should know that we will not hesitate to use force'' to protect the estimated 3,000 Soviet citizens still in Iraq. The Iraqi spokesman, whose comments were carried by the official Iraqi agency, cautioned the Soviet leadership that it would ``lose the friendship of 200 million Arabs if Soviet conduct were go further than it has go so far.'' The Soviets have two warships and a support vessel in the Gulf region, but they have not apparently taken an active part in the naval force blockading Iraq. Moscow has a friendship treaty with Baghdad and was its main arms supplier during the 1980-88 war with Iran. The Soviets have played a key mediation role in the gulf crisis but failed to convince Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. Sarkis Arkilian, a Soviet Oil Ministry official, was visiting Baghdad on Sunday to discuss the status of 3,000 Soviets, mainly technicians and oil specialists, who have not been able to leave Iraq. Soviet diplomats declined to give any details of Arkilian's talks with Gen. Hussein Kamel Hassan, Iraq's acting oil minister and Saddam's son-in-law. Some 2 million foreigners, mostly Asians and Arabs but including several thousand Americans and Europeans, remain in Kuwait and Iraq. They include some 600 Americans, Britons and others held as ``human shields'' at strategic locations to deter attack by the the force confronting Iraq. No Soviets are believed to be among the ``human shields.''

DOC.HEAD: Muhammad Ali Flies Out With Freed U.S. Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to lower number of hostages on plane to 33, ADD that Belgians flew out on Belgian airliner; EDITS to conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former boxer Muhammad Ali flew out of Baghdad on Sunday with 15 American hostages whose freedom he secured in talks with President Saddam Hussein, airport officials said. Two Canadians and six British hostages, released seperately by the Iraqis, were also on the Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad, spokesmen for the groups said. Airport officials in Baghdad said 10 more Westerners, who were not further identified, also were on board. The officials said 24 Belgians flew to Brussels Sunday afternoon in a Belgian airliner that had brought medicine to Iraq. The Iraqi Airways plane carrying the 33 hostages landed in Amman at 1:34 p.m. (5:34 EST) after a 90-minute flight from the Iraqi capital. All the Americans were men who had been held at strategic facilities in Iraq and Kuwait as ``human shields'' against attacks by the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf. U.S. Embassy officials welcomed Ali and the American hostages. U.S. officials had earlier said Ali's trip to Iraq was private. The group had originally been scheduled to leave Saturday, but Ali decided to stay on, hoping to use the good will generated by President Bush's offer to hold talks with Iraq to win the release of more Americans. Bush offered Friday to send Secretary of State James Baker III to Baghdad for talks on resolving the gulf crisis, triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq on Saturday agreed to the idea of peace talks. But the Iraqis apparently refused to free any more of the estimated 330 U.S. citizens still held in Iraq, at least 100 of them as human shields. Another 600 remain in hiding in Kuwait. Ali, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, spent more than a week in Baghdad with two aides and two members of the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. He met last week with Saddam and other senior Iraqi officials in his mission to win the release of hostages. Jaber Mohammed, the former boxer's manager, said Saturday that Ali might return later this month to seek the release of more Americans. On Friday, a group of about 80 foreigners, most of them Swedes, were released and flew to Stockholm in a chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner. An Ali associate, Arthur Morrison, earlier identified the 15 Americans as George Charchalis of Reno, Nevada; Ralph Leidholdt of Lakewood, Colorado; Richard Iliff of Roswell, Georgia; Harold Martin of Tulsa, Oklahoma; Dean Shannon of Cuero, Texas; Bobby Means of Belle Chasse, Louisiana; R.L. Smart of Liberty, Texas; Desmond Bailey of Crosby, Texas; Bobby R. Anderson of Round Rock, Texas; Harry Brill-Edwards of Fort Lee, New Jersey; Sergio Coletta of Moss Point, Mississippi; and Ken Beasley, Marlin Gillmore, Julio Loyala and Bill McHann, all of Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Urges Voters to Cast Ballots in Historic Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to CORRECT in lead that elections are first free balloting in 58 years sted 41, and in 7th graf that interview was published Sunday sted Saturday; pickup 8th graf pvs, `The first...'
DOC.TEXT: United Germany on Sunday held its first free elections in 58 years since Adolf Hitler seized power and led the country into World War II and partition. The polls opened under dreary skies with snow and light rain. About 60 million people were eligible to choose the government for the newly united nation, but initial reports said turnout was low. Germany's leaders were among the first to vote. Chancellor Helmut Kohl cast his ballot at noon in his hometown of Oggersheim, 65 miles south of Frankfurt after attending church. Kohl and his Christian Democrats are widely favored to win because of his strong leadership in uniting the two Germanys. His main challenger, leftist Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine, voted in Saarbruecken in southwestern Germany, the capital of Saarland state where he serves as governor. Kohl said Germans had paid a high price for democracy and urged them to vote. ``Many people fought peacefully for the right to vote freely for decades. They often suffered prison or worse. This right is one of democracy's most precious treasures,'' Kohl said in an interview published Sunday. The first projected results were expected at 6:30 p.m. (12:30 p.m. EST), 30 minutes after the polls close. The momentous occasion was overshadowed Saturday by disclosure that an arrest warrant had been issued for former East German Communist chief Erich Honecker on charges he gave shoot-to-kill orders at the Berlin Wall. Honecker, 78, is accused of personally giving shoot-to-kill orders at the Berlin Wall, a city justice official said. He said the warrant links Honecker directly to the deaths of several people trying to escape East Germany. Honecker ruled East Germany for 18 years until a peaceful revolution in October 1989 swept him from power. The events led to the unification of Germany on Oct. 3. Sunday's vote puts the final democratic seal on the yearlong drama of German unity that abolished the one-party state of East Germany and merged it with democratic West Germany. Twelve million former East Germans were joining 48 million former West Germans at the polls. Together, they were electing a new 656-member Parliament and the first chancellor of reunited Germany. Germany last voted freely as one nation in November 1932. Two months later, Adolf Hitler was named chancellor and soon rammed through laws depriving non-Nazis of their seats in parliament. The disastrous defeat in World War II left Germany divided. Kohl, who as chancellor guided West Germany to unity with its eastern neighbor, automatically became the leader of all Germany when the two states merged. A poll by the respected Allensbach Institute published Saturday predicted Kohl's Christian Democrats and their Bavarian sister party, the Christian Socialists, would earn 42.5 percent of the vote. Kohl's junior coalition partner, the Free Democrats, bolstered by the growing popularity of their leader, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, were likely to receive 10 percent, the poll said. The opposition Social Democrats, still trying to recover from their early resistance to quick unification, were expected to receive no better than 34.5 percent of the vote, the Allensbach poll indicated. No margin of error was given. Confident that voters will confirm the course he steered to unity, Kohl made only one-fourth as many campaign appearances as Lafontaine, his Social Democratic challenger. Voters apparently will not erase communism from Germany's political scene. The Party for Democratic Socialism, the reform-minded successor to East Germany's former Communist Party, is expected to win seats in the new Parliament, acccording to the Allensbach poll. Party leader Gregor Gysi told his supporters that every vote for his group was a vote to uphold socialist ideals. His comments appeared in a front-page editorial in Neues Deutschland, the party newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Radio City's Rockettes Dead at 91
DOC.TEXT: Russell Markert, who founded Radio City Music Hall's Rockettes and choreographed their high-kicking routines for 39 years, has died. He was 91. Markert, who retired in 1971, died Saturday at Waterbury Hospital. Markert himself was a dancer in Broadway shows in the 1920s. He was performing in ``No, No, Nanette'' in 1925 when he went to St. Louis to realize his dream of producing a chorus line of tall female dancers. The group he formed, ``The 16 Missouri Rockets,'' began performing in St. Louis and later toured as ``The American Rockets.'' They attracted the attention of the noted New York showman Samuel ``Roxy'' Rothafel, who hired them as ``Russell Markert's 32 Roxyettes.'' When Rothafel was hired in 1932 to open the Radio City Music Hall in New York's Rockefeller Center, Markert and the chorus line came along and changed its name to the ``Rockettes.'' His work was performed by more than 2,500 women. Born in Jersey City, N.J., in 1899, Markert began dancing in grammar school, and later took dance lessons as therapy for a foot injury he suffered in World War I. Nearly 450 Rockettes, alumnae and friends attended a charity ball honoring his 90th birthday. Proceeds benefited the Russell Markert Dance Scholarship at the Juilliard School in New York. Markert lived alone at a retirement home. Friends said he had no surviving family. The hospital said the cause of death would not be released.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Says Deposed Chadian Leader Killed Trying To Flee
DOC.TEXT: The deposed leader of Chad, Hissene Habre, was killed while trying to flee his country and the rebel forces that brought down his government, the Libyan news agency reported Sunday. The dispatch by JANA, monitored in Rome, quoted unidentified sources in the Chadian capital as saying Habre was killed near the Sudanse border and that several of his aides were arrested. Some of the aides did manage to escape, it said. The report could not immediately be confirmed independently. Libya declared earlier that Habre was a ``brigand'' and hailed the victory of the rebels. It is believed to have helped arm the guerrillas. Diplomatic sources in N'Djamena said on Saturday that Habre fled the capital on a military cargo plane and flew to Cameroon. But JANA said Habre was killed in the area between Tine and Oum Chalouba near Sudan. ``The reports by news media on the escape of Habre with his family on board an aircraft to a neighboring country were not true,'' said the brief dispatch. It gave no further details. It was not immediately known whether his family had been killed. Habre fled after rebel leader Idriss Deby scored a series of battlefield victories last week. Deby rolled into N'Djamena, the Chadian capital, on Sunday in a black Mercedes escorted by 20 all-terrain vehicles. His guerrillas began taking over key areas of the city and imposed a curfew after a day of widespread looting. Bada Maldom, vice president of Deby's Patriotic Salvation Front, held talks with National Assembly President Alingue Bawayeu, the highest-ranking official left after Habre fled. No disclosures were made about the talks. They were believed to be concerned with handing over power to Deby. Deby helped Habre, 48, oust former President Goukouni Oueddei from power in 1982. He served as defense minister until Habre accused him of plotting a coup in April 1989.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Baker: U.S. Won't Attack if Iraq Withdraws From Kuwait, Frees Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III promised Saddam Hussein on Sunday that the United States will not attack Iraq if Iraqi troops are withdrawn from Kuwait and Western hostages are freed. ``There has never been any suggestion that force would be used if the U.N. resolutions are fully complied with,'' Baker said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``If he complied with the resolutions, his reward for that would not be a military attack by the United States,'' Baker said. Those resolutions call for the unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, the release of all hostages and the restoration of the Kuwaiti government. A U.S.-led multilateral force has arrayed more than 350,000 troops against Saddam in the Persian Gulf. U.S. forces, now numbering more 240,000, are expected to swell to around 400,000 by next month. And a U.N. Security Council resolution passed last week authorized force against Saddam if he does not pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. Baker said there was an ``excellent chance'' Saddam will quit Kuwait because he knows he would face devastating military action if U.S. troops moved against him. U.S. officials - including President Bush - have voiced serious concern about Saddam's possession of chemical weapons and his program to develop nuclear weapons. While the United States remains concerned about Saddam's weapons, Baker said ``We would have to find a way to address those issues'' in the aftermath of a resolution of the Kuwaiti crisis. Bush has said he wants Baker to travel to Iraq sometime before Jan. 15 to have talks with Saddam. The president has also invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to the United States next week. Baker reiterated the U.S. position that he would not negotiate on the U.N. resolutions. U.S. officials Saturday also said the talks would not be linked with the Israeli occupation of Arab lands, as the Iraqi government has demanded.

DOC.HEAD: Man Throws Smoke Bomb At Emperor's Motorcade
DOC.TEXT: Two people threw a smoke bomb and a firecracker at Emperor Akihito's motorcade Sunday as it headed for the Imperial Palace in Kyoto after another of the rites of Akihitio's enthronement, police said. A bystander suffered an eye injury as the firecracker landed among people watching the motorcade pass, said an official of the Kyoto state police. The man and woman, who were arrested immediately, did not respond to police investigators' questions, the official said. He said they might be connected with radical leftists who declared in leaflets last Thursday that they would ``completely crush'' the royal couple's visit to Kyoto and nearby Nara. Leftist groups oppose the monarchy and say Japan's emperor system is a symbol of militarism. The smoke bomb landed in the road, pouring out smoke a minute before the car carrying Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko reached the spot, the official said. The car slowed, but Akihito might not have noticed the incident, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Financing Scandals Beset Troubled Government
DOC.TEXT: Accusations that intelligence officers murdered a homosexual pastor and recruited male prostitutes to entrap public figures are the latest problems for Premier Michel Rocard's troubled Socialist government. The scandals, and allegations that Justice Minister Henri Nallet broke fund-raising laws in running President Francois Mitterrand's 1988 re-election campaign, add to other recent woes: student protests, ghetto riots and Rocard's narrow defeat - by only five votes - of a no-confidence vote introduced by the opposition. One opinion poll indicated half the French people believe politicians are ``rather corrupt'' and one-quarter think they are liars. ``When the left was elected in 1981, they looked much cleaner than the right,'' said Pascal Perrineau, assistant director of the Center for Studies on French Political Life, a private think tank. ``Now, many voters are beginning to see the left isn't so pure,'' he said. ``They appear to have the same morality as the right. In the end, this only serves Jean-Marie Le Pen.'' Le Pen, leader of the extreme-right National Front, advocates expelling Moslem immigrants and denounces the political establishment as corrupt. The controversy about the intelligence agency Renseignements Generaux (General Information) has fascinated France for months. The agency's main task is gathering information about threats to state security, but it also investigates prostitution, narcotics and white-collar crime. On July 19, Joseph Douce, 45, a former Baptist clergyman who performed homosexual marriages, vanished after two men claiming to be policemen visited his Paris apartment. Three months later, a man gathering mushrooms in a forest discovered a body half-devoured by animals. An autopsy proved it was Douce. The intelligence service had been investigating Douce, a militant homosexual expelled from the French Baptist Church in 1975 in connection with a child prostitution ring. Two weeks before the abduction, agents fired a shot at the home of a man they wanted to infiltrate Douce's entourage. A police inquiry led to the questioning of three agents. Two have have been suspended and the third, Inspector Jean-Marc Dufourg, 34, was fired Nov. 23 after talking about the case in several media interviews. Dufourg claimed his superiors ordered him to hire a young homosexual to compromise former Justice Minister Pierre Arpaillange and Philippe Guilhaume, chief of the Antenne 2 television channel. Dufourg's allegations led to numerous reports about the intelligence service. It is said to have stolen mail from Communist Party offices, planted agents in a conservative party's headquarters and burgled the offices of a prominent anti-racism group. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe has authorized a parliamentary inquiry into the intelligence agency. Afterward, an independent body will be created to oversee police activities. Joxe also has faced pressure because of a best-seller by a whistle-blowing police inspector, Antoine Gaudino. His book, ``The Impossible Inquiry,'' alleges that laundered money and illegal kickbacks from public works contractors financed the Socialist election victory in 1988. The title comes from Gaudino's frustrated attempts in 1989 to investigate a Marseille building scandal. Gaudino wrote that he and his partner discovered notes from meetings between Socialist Party leaders and members of a fraudulent political consulting firm. He said they set up a scheme in which contractors would pay a percentage of project costs as campaign contributions to Socialist candidates. The book plunged Nallet, who had just been appointed justice minister, into controversy. Nallet was Mitterrand's treasurer in the last nine weeks of the campaign - too short a time, he says, to have learned of illicit financial activities. Joxe suspended Gaudino for ``grave indiscretion.''

DOC.HEAD: Gap Between Rich and Poor Increasing in Western Nations
DOC.TEXT: The United States was not the only Western industrialized nation to see the gap between rich and poor widen during the last decade, a government study notes, despite critics' charges that recent government policies contributed to the growth of earnings inequality. According to a study, which is forthcoming in the statistical publication Review of Income and Wealth, the same thing was happening in other countries with different policies. ``This may suggest that the causes of greater inequality are related more generally to phenomena occurring across nations rather than to specific factors unique to one country,'' say three Census Bureau economists who authored the study. ``The increase in inequality in the United States is well documented,'' said Gordon Green, assistant chief of the Housing and Household Economic Statistics Division of the bureau and one of the authors of the study. ``There has been hardly anything available on other countries, because the data hasn't been available, but the increase in inequality occurred elsewhere even though their employment experiences were very different and there were policy differences and different institutional settings,'' Green said. ``We haven't really pinned down exactly what's going on,'' he said, and further study will be needed to look into the causes. ``Maybe it has something to do with the kind of jobs that are created and the skill requirements for those jobs.'' In its annual report on income and poverty, issued in September, the Census Bureau said the wealthiest one-fifth of families received 46.8 percent of household income during 1989. This was no higher than in 1988, but was up significantly from percentages of 44.2 percent in 1979 and 43 percent in 1969. ``There seems little doubt that the income distribution has become somewhat less equal over the past 20 years,'' the bureau said in that report. It said it did not know why. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the congressional Joint Economic Committee, said, ``Those at the top of the scale are receiving an ever-larger share of the pie.'' The new comparative study says ``evidence now exists that the phenomenon of growing earnings inequality may have an international or global dimension.'' Green was joined in the study by John Coder, a statistician economist; and Paul Ryscavage, a labor economist. They said it did not necessarily reflect the views of the Census Bureau. The study compares earnings of male heads of household, aged 25 to 54, working full-time year around, in the United States, Canada, Sweden, Australia and West Germany. The figures from the different countries were not all for the same year, but were all in the mid-1980's. In the United States, the top 10 percent of households had 22.8 percent of the earnings, higher than in any other country. The top 10 percent earned 18.9 percent in Canada, 18 percent in West Germany, 17.7 percent in Sweden, and 17.4 percent in Australia. The lowest 10 percent of Americans earned 3.4 percent, lower than any of the other countries except Canada, at 2.9 percent. Australia measured 3.8 percent and West Germany 5.6 percent. The poor were best off in Sweden, with 6.3 percent of the earnings. The economists then used six different methods of measuring income inequality, applying them to the same group of workers, and found that the United States was the most unequal of the five countries by four of the methods. Canada was the most unequal by the other two. Sweden had the greatest equality by all methods of measurement. Again limiting their study to male heads of household aged 25 to 54, the study found that the share of the top one-fifth in the United States increased from 34.8 percent in 1979 to 37.4 percent in 1986, while the share of the lowest fifth dropped from 9.3 percent to 8.5 percent. In Canada, between 1981 and 1987, the wealthiest fifth increased from 31.4 to 33.4 and the poorest dropped from 10.5 to 8.5. In Sweden in the same years, the richest went from 30.8 percent to 30.2 percent and the poorest from 13.7 percent to 13.5 percent. In Australia, between 1981 and 1985, the wealthiest went from 30.7 to 31.2 and the poorest from 11.3 to 10.5. In West Germany, the gain for the wealthiest between 1981 and 1984 was only 30.8 to 31.6 per cent, while the share of the poor dropped only from 12.8 percent to 12.5 percent. The average rate of employment growth during the periods measured was 1.5 percent in the United States, 1.3 percent in Canada and 1.1 percent in Australia. It was less than half of one percent in Sweden. In West Germany, employment was declining.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Stab Israelis On Bus Outside Tel Aviv, Killing One
LaserPhotos TLV1,101
DOC.TEXT: Three Palestinians boarded a bus on a busy street outside Tel Aviv Sunday, knifed a Jewish yeshiva student to death and wounded three people, police said. A policeman killed one of the attackers, and the two others were wounded. Stunned bystanders looked on as frightened passengers, some dripping blood, poured out of the bus into a busy shopping area in Ramat Gan, a city adjacent to Tel Aviv. It was the bloodiest incident in greater Tel Aviv, Israel's most populous area, since Arabs began a wave of stabbing attacks on Jews in October. The attacks followed the poice slaying of Arabs on Jerusalem's Temple Mount. Palestinian militants, in clandestine leaflets, had declared Sunday ``a day of escalation'' of their 3-year-old struggle against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Knifings have been more common in Jerusalem, home to a greater mix of Arab and Jewish populations. The coastal Tel Aviv metropolis 40 miles away has been seen as a relatively trouble-free area. The three attackers were from the West Bank village of Azmut near Nablus, army radio said. They had boarded the Tel Aviv-bound bus in the Jewish suburb of Pardes Katz, and sat in the back seat. Soon after boarding, they jumped up shouting ``Allahu Akbar! (God is Great) witnesses said. The driver, David Shelef, said he saw the Arabs in his rear-view mirror ``jumping in the air, waving knives in their hands and lunging at the passengers seated in front of them.'' He said he braked, opened the doors to let out his approximately 20 passengers, and approached the Arabs with his pistol. Shelef said he fired one shot in the air, told them to sit still and they obeyed. Meanwhile, a bomb disposal officer from the border police, who was stopped in traffic behind the stalled bus, heard shouts of ``Terrorist! They've stabbed someone! Get out quick, bring the Uzi!'' The officer, who did not give his name, said he loaded his submachine gun and ran to the bus. He said he held the Arabs at bay for a few minutes, ordering them repeatedly in Hebrew and Arabic to keep still. But then ``one of them got up and tried to attack me, apparently with a knife. I was forced to fire to injure him and apparently the guy died on the spot.'' Israel army radio said another attacker was hit in the hand with a bullet and a third was beaten by bystanders. The injured Israelis and Arabs were rushed to nearby Beilinson Hospital. Baruch Heisler, 24, a student at a yeshiva, or religious seminary, died on the operating table of wounds to the heart and lungs, hospital officials said. The other Jewish victims were identified as Shmuel Cohen, 15, Becky Malka, 18, and Avisha Cohen, 18. They were said to have slight to moderate injuries. The attackers were not named. Becky Malka said she and a friend had been on a shopping spree when the attack happened. ``We got on the bus and behind us were three Arabs. Suddenly they shouted `Allahu Akbar' and stabbed us. They had kitchen knives,'' she said. Bystanders and shopkeepers, some of them armed, tried to beat the attackers as they were taken off the bus. One man was arrested for attacking the injured Arab as he was carried away on a stretcher. ``Anyone who tries to attack an injured man, whoever that man is, will be arrested. ... We are not animals,'' said Yaacov Raz, a commander of the greater Tel Aviv police force. Arabs on a Tel Aviv-bound bus would have attracted little attention, since thousands ride in daily from the occupied territories to jobs in Israel. Yigal Marcus, commander of Tel Aviv police, said Sunday's attack meant ``Tel Aviv has returned to the map. ``If anyone thought they (the Arabs) had forgotten Tel Aviv and were only trying to stab in Jerusalem, reality has slapped them in the face,'' Marcus said. In the Oct. 8 Temple Mount killings, police opened fire on Palestinian rioters. The government put the death toll at 20, but the Palestine Human Rights Information Center has put the toll at 17.

DOC.HEAD: Poor Atlanta Residents Fear They Will Be Victims of Olympics
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Dean stopped in front of the stadium site for the 1996 Summer Olympics, and sighed at the sight of crumbling homes and crime-ridden streets. ``People always say, `What's wrong with the people of Summerhill? They don't have the Olympic spirit,''' the former state legislator said of his once-thriving black neighborhood. ``Why should we give up everything when nobody comes to help us?'' Dean is among many activists who believe the city, so proud of its Olympic conquest since it was chosen in September to play host for the Games, will cover up or bulldoze urban blight before the world comes to Atlanta in 1996. They fear builders will raze pockets of public housing and crumbling homes to make way for Olympic facilities, adding to the city's estimated 10,000 homeless. Summerhill has seen the phenomenon before. The city razed hundreds of homes there in 1964 for Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. ``We ha a drugstore, a five-and-dime, anything you needed right here, but the stadium kicked it all out,'' said Larry Swann, 52, who grew up in the area and owns a ramshackle Summerhill house. ``There's no telling what they're going to do.'' Atlanta Olympic officials insist their plans call for no home destruction but admit the final authority - the still-unformed Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games - could change plans. ``We're frustrated that we cannot respond with something more specific,'' said Olympic spokesman Bob Brennan. ``But we got the Games (11) weeks ago and they're going to be six years from now - we need a little breathing room.'' John Leak, vice president of the business-supported planning group Central Atlanta Progress, said a brochure produced by the Atlanta Organizing Committee may be a warning: The drawings show glistening architecture and pristine landscaping but nowhere are actual pictures of the inner-city areas. The two most affected areas are Summerhill and Techwood Homes, a housing project across from Georgia Tech, where the Olympic Village, home to 16,500 athletes, will be built. The village later would provide student housing for Georgia Tech, Georgia State University and the Atlanta University Center, according to a committee proposal. ``If you just take the pretty drawings that now exist and try to place them on the sites depicted, there are certain buildings that are affected,'' he said. For example, the plan shows the Olympic stadium built on the south parking lot of the existing stadium. But drawn to scale, it would infringe on an existing home for the elderly and a hospital. ``Looking at that plan, you also don't see any provision for cars to be parked. That naturally makes (residents) nervous,'' Leak added. ``Something's got to give.'' Activists for the poor say the plans are typical of Atlanta. They have accused Mayor Maynard Jackson of trying to push the homeless from downtown. Jackson also supported a recent proposal to ban begging, although backers of the idea now propose to make begging a crime only when the panhandler accosts someone. ``This is a city that believes in hiding its poor,'' said Sister Carol Schlicksup of People for Urban Justice. ``The city isn't going to let the poor be seen by the world. The Olympics is going to devastate the poor communities. ``They keep telling us they have no money to build us the emergency single-family housing Maynard Jackson promised us,'' she said. ``But when you talk about Olympics, all of a sudden there's lots of money.'' Central Atlanta Progress, residents and activists have protested to Brennan that the Olympic committee never talked to residents before creating the Olympic plan. They also charge the committee gives more consideration to richer areas. The AOC agreed to move the Olympic tennis center out of Blackburn Park after DeKalb County residents protested. ``It's a class thing now,'' said Columbus Ward, president of the Summerhill Neighborhood Planning Unit. ``The upper-class whites who mainly own homes said they don't want it, they listened. When the poor blacks who have mostly rental property fuss, they get no response at all. ``Well, we'll stop the stadium if we have to stand in front of the bulldozers.'' Brennan said the tennis center could be moved because 25 other communities asked to play host to it. ``We have no intention of moving ahead with any plan without involving people,'' he said. ``Many of these people have lived there all their lives, are feeling their homes threatened, and I can appreciate that.''

DOC.HEAD: California, New York Lawmakers Face Fiscal Woes
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of miles apart but united in a similar predicament, the California and New York state legislatures convene Monday for special sessions called for midyear patches on leaky state budgets. In Albany, Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo has proposed sharp cuts in state spending to deal with an estimated $1 billion deficit in New York's $50 billion budget for the fiscal year that ends March 31. Cuomo has called for state worker layoffs, mandatory and unpaid employee furloughs and cuts in state aid for education and health care. The situation is less serious in Sacramento, where Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, who leaves office in January, wants $1 billion in cuts as a fiscal cushion in California's $75 billion budget. Without those cuts, the budget for the fiscal year that ends June 30 could just break even or have a small deficit. Deukmejian has proposed $600 million in public school cuts, a $200 million reduction in the income tax credit for renters and a freeze on state hiring and purchases. For New York, this is the third straight year officials have faced state budget deficits. And next year promises to be no better: Comptroller Edward Regan has said the state may be facing a potential deficit of as much as $3 billion then. In the past, Cuomo and the Legislature have been quick to turn to tax increases to help bail themselves out when they learned that spending had exceeded revenues. Last year, New Yorkers were hit with a $1 billion tax increase package and earlier this year they were socked with a record $1.8 billion in new taxes. But last month, Cuomo won re-election to a third term with a lower percentage of the vote than expected despite being opposed by splintered and poorly funded opposition. The potential 1992 presidential candidate said the message from voters was clear - they didn't want any new taxes. That prompted Cuomo to come forth with a deficit reduction plan that relies almost entirely on spending cuts. Under the governor's plan before the Legislature, the state's $9 billion school aid package would be sliced by $200 million and social service programs would be slashed by $125 million. It provides for the firing of 2,000 state workers and 4,000 other job eliminations through attrition and early retirement incentives by the end of the fiscal year. While legislative leaders have been tinkering with Cuomo's proposals - particularly in the politically sensitive areas of school aid and health care spending - both Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Senate Majority Leader Ralph Marino have indicated they don't expect major changes. Quick approval of a Cuomo-developed plan would also leave the governor to shoulder most of the blame for politically unpopular cuts. The California special session coincides with the regular opening of the regular 1991-92 session, an opening that normally consists of swearing-in ceremonies. Deukmejian, who did not seek a third term this year, would like lawmakers to approve his ``fiscal austerity plan'' before he leaves office to assure that his final budget remains in the black. Many legislators, particularly majority Democrats, would rather wait until Republican Gov.-elect Pete Wilson is sworn in Jan. 7. Deukmejian has been particularly uncompromising in budget debates, while Wilson has more of a conciliatory reputation. The problem occurred this fall when tax revenues for the first four months of this fiscal year fell more than $400 million below estimates because of the faltering economy. The budget passed last summer had a $1.3 billion reserve, but that is expected to be depleted by the reduced revenues. Wilson has remained quiet about the budget. A $1 billion fix now would help the task he faces just three days after his inauguration. He must present the Legislature with a proposed budget for the 1991-92 fiscal year on Jan. 10. The state Commission on State Finance last week estimated there could be at least a $4.3 billion gap between estimated 1991-92 tax revenues and a current-level budget.

DOC.HEAD: A Glance at Germany's Parliamentary Election
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany on Sunday held its first free elections in a united country since 1932. Here at a glance are some issues and statistical data: AT STAKE: 656 seats in a united parliament, 328 directly chosen in their districts and 328 from party lists; head of government, or chancellor. Also a city council for Berlin, the new capital of united Germany. GETTING IN: A party needed at least 5 percent of the vote to win seats in the Bundestag, the lower house of parliament. However, the constitutional court decided that vote counts would be separate for former West Germany and East Germany. NUMBER OF ELIGIBLE VOTERS: 59.9 million - 47.9 million from former West Germany and 12 million from former East Germany. NUMBER OF VOTING DISTRICTS: 328. NUMBER OF CANDIDATES: 3,969. NUMBER OF PARTIES: 23. MAIN PARTIES: -Christian Democratic Union, CDU, and its sister party, the Bavarian Christian Social Union, CSU. They are part of a center-right alliance that is heading the current government coalition of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. -Social Democratic Party, SPD. The main opposition party, leftist. -Free Democratic Party, FDP, liberal party of the center, the junior coalition partner in the current government, whose most prominent member is popular Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. -Greens, a leftist, ecology-oriented party, which is running in the election on a joint list with Alliance 90, a similar group in former East Germany. -Party of Democratic Socialism, PDS, the leftist, renamed party of the former East German Communists. -Republicans, ultra-rightist. TOP CANDIDATES: Helmut Kohl, 60, CDU leader and incumbent chancellor, who was seeking his third four-year term. Oskar Lafontaine, 47, SPD, governor of Saarland state. The chancellor is picked by the party that wins the most seats, or in coalition talks. CAMPAIGN: Was low key, with Kohl enjoying such wide support in polls that few doubted he would win. By forging ahead full speed for a quick unification and achieving it on Oct. 3, Kohl made himself more popular than ever, particularly in former East German states. Lafontaine, who barely survived an assassination attept by a deranged woman in April, made soaring unification costs his main theme.

DOC.HEAD: First Journalist Travels into Space Aboard Soviet Rocket
LaserPhoto BAIK1
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet rocket rode a column of fire into orbit in a picture-perfect launch Sunday, carrying two cosmonauts and a Japanese television reporter who became the first journalist in space. The liftoff - which also launched a Soviet effort to commercialize their space program - was right on schedule, under bright, sunny skies on the remote Central Asian steppes of Kazakhstan. Journalist Toyohiro Akiyama, 48, joined Soviet cosmonauts Viktor Afanasyev and Musa Manarov in the Soyuz TM-11 space capsule. Akiyama was a passenger under a $12 million contract between the Soviet Union and Japan's biggest private television company, TBS. Underscoring the commercial nature of the mission, the Soviet rocket even had advertising slogans for TBS and other Japanese companies emblazoned on its sides. About an hour and a half before the Soviet launch, the U.S. space shuttle Columbia blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The flight, NASA's sixth shuttle mission this year, carried seven astronauts and an astronomical laboratory into space. With two Soviet cosmonauts already aboard the orbiting space station Mir, the two liftoffs brought to 12 the number of people in space, the most ever at one time. The Columbia crew hopes to contact the Soviet crew by radio. The Soviet rocket's fiery blastoff shook shook a reviewing stand about a mile away in this once-secret space installation, 1,200 miles east of Moscow. ``I feel fine,'' Akiyama said minutes before the 1:13 p.m. (3:13 a.m. EST) liftoff. During the eight-day mission, he will document the experience on radio and television for TBS. The Japanese television company is spending $37 million on the entire venture to mark its 40th year on the air, according to network president Izumi Tanaka. More than 120 TBS reporters, cameramen and technicians scurried about the launch control center and reviewing stand to cover the launch, even sacrificing a remote-control camera next to the rocket to watch the flames close-up before it burned. Akiyama's wife, Kyoko, called the blastoff ``beautiful,'' although she earlier said she was nervous. ``But when I saw their faces on the television screen, I calmed down and felt happier,'' she said. Akiyama, a TBS news director who quit a four-pack-a-day cigarette habit during the training, was asked before liftoff what he looked forward to most on his return from the first trip into space by a Japanese citizen. ``I can't wait to have a smoke,'' he said. Akiyama, for whom TBS bought a $2.2 million life insurance policy, carried stationery, a picture of his family and three Japanese good-luck charms into space. Tanaka, the TBS president, said the rocket ``took off just like a train on schedule.'' He said Akiyama would receive a promotion when he got back. Akiyama will return to Earth with cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov, the current Mir crew. They will end a four-month stay in space and be replaced by Manarov and Afanasyev, who will stay aboard the space station for six months. In addition to live broadcasts, Akiyama will photograph environmental damage on Earth and conduct experiments on Japanese tree frogs to see how they cope in a gravity-free environment. TBS also hopes to arrange a tlephone call Dec. 7 between Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the cosmonauts. Soviet officials and TBS executives have held out the hope that the flight could improve ties between the two countries, which never officially ended their World War II hostilities. The commercial contract boosts the Kremlin's drive to cash in on its Soyuz space program in the face of critical economic problems at home. Despite receiving about $30 million from sponsors for several weeks of live coverage and documentaries about the space program, TBS will not immediately turn a profit on the venture, Tanaka said. ``Yes, we will lose about $7.4 million, but we consider this loss the cost of TBS' growth,'' he said. The mission will be the eighth to hook up with the Mir space station since it was put into orbit in 1986. Although Soviet scientists and 14 foreign cosmonauts have ridden into space aboard Soyuz capsules, Akiyama is the first non-scientific paying passenger. Sunday's launch culminates three years of planning between the Japanese firm and Soviet officials.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Visit To Latin America Highlights Changing Agenda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush departure scheduled 6:45 p.m. EST; top planned
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's visit to South America this week comes at a time when American concerns are turning from the Cold War to economic cooperation in this hemisphere. Bush's first stop on his week-long tour was to be Brasilia, Brazil, following an overnight flight from Washington. His itinerary also includes Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela. At each stop he is expected to hail the evolution to democratic rule in Latin America and to promote his vision of a hemisphere-wide free trade zone. After a decade in whcch U.S. hemispheric policy was dominated by the political upheaval in Central America, Bush now has the luxury of having what U.S. officials like to call a ``positive agenda'' in his dealings with Latin America. Skeptics wonder about the utility of his visit at a time of crisis in the Persian Gulf, but Bush feels it is important to seize on what he regards as a moment of unique opportunity in hemispheric relations. Bush was to have made the visit in September but postponed it because of the gulf situation. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will remain in Washington to deal with that issue. Each of the countries on Bush's itinerary except Venezuela began the last decade under military rule and now has an elected president. Venezuela has had stable, democratic government since 1958. Beyond that, there is an emerging consensus in the hemisphere that radical economic reform is required to help the region escape from the ``lost decade'' of the 1980s - a period in which production, investment and consumption all fell sharply. Through his ``Enterprise for the Americas Initiative,'' unveiled last June, Bush is attempting to promote economic growth by encouraging more free trade and increased investment. Countries that adopt reform measures would be eligible for debt reduction. The emergence of democratic governments, coupled with the phasing out of the Cold War and the willingness of most countries to undertake painful economic reform, has produced an era of unusual harmony in U.S. relations in Latin America. There was a similar period in the early 1960s when President John F. Kennedy launched the Alliance for Progress, an ambitious social and economic reform program. But Kennedy's death and a wave of military coups in Latin America took the steam out of the Alliance, and hemispheric relations suffered. For more the two decades, the relationship was afflicted by divisive political disputes over such issues as human rights abuses and economic nationalism. During the last decade, there was resentment over U.S. support for Britain during the Falkland Islands crisis in 1982 and for the Nicaraguan Contras. As the 1980s ended, hemispheric condemnation for the U.S. invasion of Panama was widespread. Nowadays, the mood between the United States and its neighbors to the south is far more relaxed. There are fewer divisive issues. And communist Cuba has far less appeal as a model for other countries than it once did. ``We are at the beginning of a new era,'' says Michael Wilson, an associate at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. Some analysts believe the United States would derive immense benefits from an economically prosperous Latin America, a potentially lucrative market for U.S. manufactured exports. ``Latin America, rather than Japan, holds the key to the U.S. trade deficit,'' says Peter Drucker, a professor of the Claremont Graduate School in California. Bush has pleased many Latin countries by recognizing more than President Ronald Reagan did the need to combat the drug problem by adopting policies that reduce demand at home. For many years, the United States had caused resentment by placing more emphasis on efforts to reduce supply in producing countries. No country has received more attention from the Bush administration than Mexico. Bush has met six times in two years with President Carlos Salinas, including a two-day visit this past week in which both stressed their goal of reaching a free trade agreement. Both sides agree there is less tension in the relationship than at any time in recent memory.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germans Vote For Different Leaders, Same Dream
LaserPhoto HBG1
DOC.TEXT: They left their homes on a gray, misty morning to cast ballots for a brighter future. Even families could not agree on the candidates, but they all voted for the same thing. ``We want to have a better life,'' said Hildegard Neumann, 66, a resident of Germany's most depressed eastern region. ``Life was not so good for the past 40 years.'' Delitzsch is one of scores of smoky, smudged cities that stand amid sprawling processing plants in the south of what was once East Germany. This is Saxony state, the faintly beating heartland of the former nation's fading industrial sector. It is a stronghold of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats, who promise prosperity soon. Mrs. Neumann and her husband, Kurt, voted in Sunday's united German elections for the party they believe will deliver on its promise. ``We think that the Christian Democrats are the capitalists. They are also Christians, and we need that,'' the retired schoolteacher said. She stood outside a poll station on a cobblestone street made drearier by the fog drifting between smog-blackened buildings. Her husband marked his 69th birthday Sunday. Unlike many older people, he was not afraid of the end of Communist subsidies that gave pensioners some security. ``Our rent starts to go up in January, 15 percent. Energy and bus prices go up,'' he said. ``But I'm an optimist.'' Like Neumann, Kathleen Bobbe celebrated a birthday on Sunday, her 18th. But she said she didn't think she would exercise her new right to vote. ``I just don't know, there are so many candidates,'' said Kathleen, whose immediate goal is to go to a good school that will lead to a well-paying job. Her father's brother and his two sisters - the children of a staunch Communist - gathered with their spouses at his home to celebrate Kathleen's birthday and talk politics. Most of them favored Kohl. Kathleen's father, Klaus Bobbe, lost a factory job but recently found work in a metal-working plant in the western German city of Mannheim. He stays in a rooming house and makes an 11-hour round trip home on weekends. ``A lot of people have given up on this area,'' he said. Delitzsch is 12 miles north of Leipzig, where protests against the Communist government began last year. It is also where the rallies for German unity began. Theodor Arnold, who is married to Bobbe's oldest sister, broke with most of the family and voted for the left-leaning Social Democrats. He's angry that former Communists still run the factories. He also said the Social Democrats, the main opposition party, take human factors into account. ``Our prices are now higher than in the West, but we still only make about a third as much,'' he said. Arnold, 40, was 10 years old when his father moved the family east from the former West German city of Frankfurt. The next year, 1961, the Communists closed the borders and built the Berlin Wall. ``My father tried to get us all out again,'' he said. ``It wasn't too bad. He only had to serve five months in prison.'' Arnold speaks three languages and mimics American rock and roll on a guitar he taught himself to play. He collects models of antique cars, studies birds, tells ribald political jokes, plays soccer and holds a university mathematics degree. He bought a book, ``One Thousand Entirely Legal Ways to Avoid Paying Taxes,'' to help him understand new Western tax laws. Despite education and intellect, he toils in a struggling aluminum factory. ``I was from the West, I had family there, my father was in prison and I always argued with my professors about the Communists,'' said the father of two girls. ``It was difficult to find a job.'' Despite the Social Democratic Party stickers plastered on his tiny East German car, it is the more conservative Christian Democrats who deliver the message that captivates his neighbors. The party dominated East Germany's first free national elections in March, its local elections in May and its state elections in October. On Sunday, Benidikta Henger voted for them again in an election she said was even more important than the vote for the government that led the nation to unity. ``In March, we knew we were electing a government for only a short time,'' said the 23-year-old mother of two. ``This one will be around for a long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Ten People Die in Scattered Violence Nationwide
DOC.TEXT: Ten people died in scattered violence nationwide, police said Sunday, including five who died in a gunfight in eastern Natal Province. Nelson Mandela, meanwhile, said the African National Congress would continue its campaign of mass action against apartheid. He also reiterated that talks on ending apartheid and giving political power to the black majority would be threatened if the white-led government fails to halt chronic violence in black townships. Mandela spoke at a funeral for David Tshoga, who was killed by police in an illegal protest march. Later, the 300 people attending marched to the northern suburb of Emmerentia, where Tshoga became the first black buried at Westpark Cemetery. A police unrest report gave few details of four fatal incidents in the previous 24 hours. It said three hacked and stabbed bodies were found in the Bekkersdal black township southwest of Johannesburg, while a deputy mayor of the Khayelitsha township near Cape Town was stabbed to death. In many townships, residents oppose local leaders, whom they consider collaborators with the government and its apartheid system of racial segregation. Five people died in a clash between unidentified groups armed with guns at Table Mountain in Natal province, and four houses were also burned. The body of another man with bullet and stab wounds was found in the area, the report said. The province, the traditional Zulu homeland, has been the scene of fighting between Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party and Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. More than 5,000 people have died over five years. In August, the black factional fighting spread to black townships near Johannesburg, leaving at least 800 people dead. Both groups oppose apartheid, but they differ on the policies of a future South African government. Inkatha favors a free market system and promotion of tribal heritage, while the ANC advocates leftist and pan-tribal policies. The ANC renewed charges this week that security forces have been aiding Inkatha fighters in the violence around Johannesburg. It provided a videotape to local journalists that reportedly showed armed Inkatha members getting out of a police vehicle and leading a march in Zonkizezwe, a squatter camp hit by unrest in recent weeks. The government declared Zonkizezwe an unrest area Thursday, giving police wide detention powers and imposing a 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew. The ANC refused to say who made the videotape, but claimed it proved police were aiding Inkatha. Photos made from the videotape appeared Sunday in South African newspapers. The government has denied allegations that police and soldiers have aided Inkatha, and challenged the ANC to provide proof of complicity. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said Sunday the Inkatha members were transported in a police vehicle to negotiate with Xhosa leaders and police. He said Xhosa leaders also were transported in a police vehicle for the talks. Journalists at the scene told the Sunday Star newspaper that three Inkatha members had negotiated with police, then left the area in the police vehicle. The journalists, who were not identified, said the Inkatha members later came back and dispersed the crowd of supporters. Vlok criticized the ANC for releasing the video.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Approval Needed to Give Honecker to German Police
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Officials on Sunday sought Soviet approval to enter a Soviet military hospital near Berlin and arrest former East German Communist leader Erich Honecker on charges of manslaughter. Officials said Saturday they had issued an arrest warrant for Honecker, who was ousted last year during the peaceful East German revolution that led to German unity Oct. 3. The warrant charges that Honecker personally signed shoot-to-kill orders for guards at the Berlin Wall during his rule. It directly links him to the deaths of several people who were killed trying to flee East Germany, officials say. A Soviet diplomat said Sunday that German police need Moscow's approval to arrest Honecker at the well-guarded hospital compound where he has taken refuge with his wife. The hospital is outside Beelitz, a town in former East Germany in a forest 20 miles south of Berlin. Some German officials criticized the Soviets for not turning Honecker over immediately. There were complaints that the Soviets were trying to protect their former ally. Valery Zhilin, who identified himself as a first secretary at the Soviet General Consulate in former East Berlin, said he did not expect permission for Honecker's arrest to be granted on Sunday. ``It's a very complicated situation,'' Zhilin said in a telephone interview. ``It will be decided at the very top.'' He said that Gen. Boris V. Snetkow, the commanding officer of the Soviet forces in eastern Germany, was away on a business trip. Honecker, 78, conferred with his defense lawyers on Sunday at the hospital complex. His lawyers maintain he is too ill to stand trial. The arrest warrant was issued Friday and officials began moving against Honecker on Saturday, the eve of the first free elections in united Germany in 58 years. Walter Momper, the acting Berlin mayor, told the Bonn-based Die Welt newspaper he believed Honecker would stand trial in 1991. Some 200 people died trying to escape East Germany during the 28-year existence of the Berlin Wall and the barbed wire barrier that separated the two German states. ``The Soviet Union must get used to German sovereignty,'' Momper said in an interview. ``It cannot protect a German citizen from criminal proceedings.'' The Soviet Union and the other three World War II allies that defeated Nazi Germany had special rights in the divided land until unification, when Germany regained its sovereignty. Honecker became a citizen of united Germany when the democratic west absorbed the once communist state of East Germany on Oct. 3. ``The Soviet army cannot act as Honecker's protecting power,'' said Heiner Geissler, a board chairman of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. Testimony by Honecker could be potentially embarrassing to the Soviet leadership. In a bitter newspaper interview with the eastern Berlin daily ``Wochenpost'' two weeks ago, Honecker blamed ``Soviet authors'' for his downfall on Nov. 18, 1989. In November, Honecker told the British weekly the European that he was being offered as a ``scapegoat'' and said unidentified ``intriguers'' brought him down. The ADN news agency, quoting Honecker's lawyers, said Sunday that he denied ever giving an interview to a journalist of the London-based daily, and that a conversation he had with the author of the article was ``of a purely private nature.'' The news agency ADN reported that Honecker had not registered for Sunday's national elections and therefore were not eligible to vote.

DOC.HEAD: Sotthern Democrats Showing Increasing Discontent With House Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Southern Democrats, whose influence in the House has been declining steadily in recent years, are showing increasing signs of discontent with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and his leadership team. While few Southerners are openly critical of Foley, D-Wash,. their growing unrest has become evident in the maneuvering for this week's House leadership elections. Rep. Jimmy Hayes, D-La., who is bidding for one of two open seats on the House Appropriations Committee, has been circulating a map of the United States among members of the Democratic Steering and Policy Committee, the Foley-dominated group that makes committee assignments. The map shows the districts of the 10 Democrats who have filled key leadership and committee posts since House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, resigned last year. All 10 are from districts located north of a line drawn from Sacramento to Washington. ``I think that makes the case clearly,'' said Rep. Claude Harris, D-Ala., who is campaigning for one of the Southern regional seats on the steering and policy committee. ``We need more representation from our region.'' ``I really see a writing off of the South,'' said Rep. Ed Jenkins, D-Ga., who was defeated by Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., last year in the race for House majority leader. ``They'll accept a socialist a lot easier than they will accept a conservative Southern Democrat,'' said Jenkins, referring to Vermont Rep.-elect Bernie Sanders' bid to join the Democratic caucus. ``It is not, I don't think, a conscious thing, but we're simply not being well represented as a region,'' Jenkins said in an interview last week. After Jenkins lost his bid for majority leader, Foley promised he would consider Southern conservatives when making appointments in an effort to ``provide some additional balance in the leadership.'' An aide to Foley said Sunday that ``a very great attempt'' has been made to do fulfill that pledge. He noted that Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., served as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. But ``the leadership still is cognizant of the desire to have a so-called Southern leadership person ... in the smaller circle,'' said the aide, who spoke only on condition he not be named. He said the appointment of another Southerner to a leadership position is also being considered. The aide and another Foley staffer predicted Sanders, who ran as an Independent, would not be elected to the Democratic Caucus. Harris, in his bid for the steering and policy seat, has been reminding his Southern colleagues that they have little say in committee assignments, in setting the agenda of the House or in scheduling legislation. ``Our problem in particular is that our folks haven't been as vocal as those from other parts of the country,'' Harris said. ``We've got to get in there and work to make sure our voice is heard.'' Southern Democrats like Harris, 50, and Jenkins, 57, say efforts to land new leadership and committee slots for the region are particularly crucial now, since much of the South's influence in Congress comes from aging committee and subcommittee chairman. In the appropriations committee, for example, the five Southerners who chair subcommittees range in age from 60 to 81. On the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, only six of the 23 members are from the South, and two of those, both subcommittee chairmen, are over 70. ``If you look at the numbers and see all the people coming on (major committees) from outside our region ... there's no question there's going to be fewer and fewer'' Southerners in influential positions, Harris said. Jenkins, who has argued for years that the South is the key that can unlock the White House for Democrats, said the House leadership's failure to include Southern conservatives in their inner councils can only further erode support for the party in the South. ``The end result,'' he said, ``is that they can make these appointments or they won't have to anyway because it will be all Republicans.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Return Remains of Unknown Italian Soldier
DOC.TEXT: The remains of an Italian Unknown Soldier who died in the Soviet Union during World War II were formally given to Italian authorities at a military cemetery on Sunday. The remains symbolized the 90,000 Italians who died on the Russian front while fighting with the German army against the Soviets. The arrival of the urn at the military cemetery at Redipuglia in northern Italy marked the beginning of a program in which Italian remains from World War II are to be exhumed in the Soviet Union and sent home. An accord on the program is to be signed in Moscow in January. A Soviet military delegation and Italian President Francesco Cossiga attended Sunday's ceremony. ``The return of the Unknown Soldier is a sign of the times,'' said Defense Minister Virginio Rognoni at the ceremony in front of a military shrine. ``With the disintegration of the walls that divided peoples, with freedom and dialogue returning to many parts of the world through perestroika, Italy and the USSR feel like neighbors.'' About 40,000 people attended the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Test-Fires Missiles, Allied Forces Take `Precautions'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thuout to UPDATE with Cheney comment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq launched surface-to-surface missiles Sunday in what appeared to be test firings, U.S. and British military officials said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said they may have been SCUD missiles. There were reports that allied forces in the Persian Gulf went on alert, but U.S. military officials refused to discuss that. In Washington, Cheney confirmed the firings and said they were apparently SCUD missiles ``or SCUD variants.'' He said the test tok place entirely within Iraqi territory. He said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has used SCUD missiles in the past with conventional warheads. But he said the missiles, which have a range of up to 400 miles, ``could conceivably carry chamical weapons.'' ``They're not very accurate - accurate enough to hit a city, not accurate enough to hit a point target,'' Cheney said in an interview on ABC-TV. The defense secretary said the last such test launch was in April, four months before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``It's, I think, proof again, if anybody needed any, that he does in fact have ballistic missiles and the capacity to use them,'' Cheney said. The U.S. military's General Information Bureau in Saudi Arabia released a terse statement about the incident. ``We received indications this morning that Iraqi armed forces conducted activity that included the firing of surface-to-surface missiles within Iraq,'' the statement said. ``The flight path of the missiles was away from U.S. and coalition forces.'' The U.S. and British officials did not say how many missiles were fired or what type they were. Nor would they say how the missiles were detected, but they were apparently monitored either by U.S. spy satellites or AWACS airborne early-warning radar planes, which are on patrol around Iraq and Kuwait 24 hours a day. None of the allied officials would say whether an alert was ordered among the 240,000 U.S. military personnel and the 150,000-member allied force, including 16,000 Britons, massed in the region. ``We are aware of missile activity within Iraq earlier today and the necessary precuations were taken by British forces,'' said a British Defense Ministry spokesman in London, speaking on condition of anonymity. Troops in the region were reported to have been put on ``yellow alert'' last Thursday when the U.N. Security Council passed a resolution giving Iraq until Jan. 15 to leave Kuwait or face possible military action. Yellow alert status is one category below full combat alert.

DOC.HEAD: Whoopi Goldberg, Morgan Freeman Honored with NAACP Awards
DOC.TEXT: Actress-comedian Whoopi Goldberg, rap star M.C. Hammer and actors Morgan Freeman and James Earl Jones were among those honored at the 23rd annual NAACP Image Awards. The civil war drama ``Glory'' was named best motion picture and Fox Television's ``In Living Color'' won best TV comedy program at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People's ceremony honoring black achievement. The Saturday night award show will be televised Jan. 16 on NBC. Recording nominees Oleta Adams, Randy Crawford, Miki Howard and Dianne Reeves performed a tribute to the late jazz legend Sarah Vaughan. Vaughan was presented posthumously with a Hall of Fame Award. Miss Goldberg was named black Entertainer of the Year and also won best supporting actress honors for her role as a spiritualist in this year's box office smash ``Ghost.'' Singer Dionne Warwick received the Key of Life Award from singer-composer Stevie Wonder to recognize her commitment to fighting AIDS and other diseases. In the special awards category, the President's Award for public service was presented to Antoinette Stroman, 20, who has battled viral encephalitis. Hall of Fame awards were given to retired dancer Katherine Dunham and actor Jones. Former Los Angeles Dodgers catcher Roy Campanella and Olympic bronze medalist Anita DeFrantz were recipients of the Jackie Robinson Sports Achievement Award. Attorney Conrad Lynn took the Roy Wilkins Civil Rights Award. The award for best film actor was presented to Freeman for his role as a chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' No award was given this year for best female actress; at the time the nominations were announced in October, the group said in a statement that it regretted the paucity of roles for black women actresses and added that the lack of nominees in the category was a sign of ``the imbalance and irresponsibility of the film industry.'' Oscar winner Denzel Washington received honors for best supporting actor for his role in ``Glory.'' In the music category, Quincy Jones won the best album award for ``Back on the Block,'' and Luther Vandross received best male recording artist honors. Best vocal groups honors went to the Whispers for their album ``More of the Night,'' and Etta James won best blues artist for her singing on ``Stickin' to My Guns.'' Best rap group was M.C. Hammer for ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em.'' Anita Baker won best female artist for ``Compositions,'' and the Winans were named best gospel artists for ``Return.'' A group called After 7 won the award for best new male group award for its album ``After 7,'' while En Vogue received the best new female group honor with ``Born to Sing,'' and best jazz artist was presented to Jonathan Butler for ``Deliverance.'' In the TV category, executive producer Keenen Ivory Wayans of ``In Living Color'' won best comedy series and producers Fred Silverman and Carroll O'Connor were awarded best dramatic series honors for ``In the Heat of the Night.'' For TV comedy, Kadeem Hardison and Jasmine Guy were named best actor and actress for their roles in ``A Different World.''
