DOC.HEAD: Baker Sends Israel Message of Reassurance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has sent a message to his Israeli counterpart assuring him that Washington's overtures toward Iraq do not signify a change in U.S. policy, Israel radio said Sunday. Foreign Minister David Levy, who read the message to the Cabinet during its weekly meeting, expressed satisfaction with the U.S. clarifications. ``There is no change in the United States' position. There is no change in its principles against aggression, and there is no change in its opposition to any kind of linkage between Iraqi aggression and the Arab-Israel conflict,'' Levy told Israel radio. But Levy also warned that if Saddam Hussein is allowed to keep his weapons of mass destruction he will remain a threat to Israel, the Middle East and Europe, as well as to the world's economy, the radio said. Baker apparently sent the message to reassure Israel after President Bush offered to send Baker to Iraq to discuss a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis, which began with Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush has also invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to Washington. Iraq accepted the offer, but demanded a ``serious and deep dialogue'' that would include the Palestinian question. Saddam has repeatedly declared he would negotiate a withdrawal from Kuwait if the Israelis pull out of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which were captured in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The United States has rejected any such linkage. Science Minister Yuval Neeman from the right-wing Tehiya Party drew criticism for remarks Sunday that any U.S.-Iraq talks would threaten Israel. He said an agreement between Iraq and the United States would come at Israel's expense, and equated a visit by Baker to Baghdad with former British Prime Minster Neville Chamberlain's meeting with Adolf Hitler in Munich prior to World War II. At that time, Chamberlain believed Hitler was a rational statesman and in 1938 signed the Munich Pact, which surrendered parts of Czechoslovakia to the Nazis without that country's agreement. ``I am very much afraid that from a strong posture that (Bush) took until now he has now moved into one that could represent appeasement,'' Neeman said on Israel Television. ``My impression is that if this will be the process, then we are in the position of Czechoslovakia and this is what we have to prevent.'' Levy said Neeman's statements were damaging and did not represent the opinion of the Israeli government. ``The Cabinet certainly disagrees with them,'' Levy said. Bush made his offer last week after the U.N. Security Council voted to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if it has not withdrawn from the oil-rich emirate by Jan. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Replaces Interior Minister
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday named former KGB general Boris Pugo as Interior Minister after relieving Vadim Bakatin of the job in a possible shakeup of the country's law and order ministry. Gorbachev ``released Vadim Bakatin from the duties of the Soviet interior minister in connection with his transition to another job,'' the state news agency Tass reported. Bakatin's replacement must be approved by the Supreme Soviet legislature, the report said. The report did not say whether the 53-year-old Bakatin was being promoted or punished. Officials have said there has been a sharp rise in economic and violent crime stemming from the nation's political crisis. Gorbachev has been threatening a crackdown for more than a month. He has also said that he planned drastic changes in the government structure, especially the Council of Ministers headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. The prime minister is widely blamed for the failure of the government's economic reforms. Pugo, 53, was first secretary of the Communist Party in the Baltic republic of Latvia in 1984-88, but was forced out due to the growing independence movement there. Pugo becomes the most prominent Baltic native in a Communist Party and government leadership that is dominated by Russians. He is not considered popular in Latvia, however, because he was deputy chief and chief of the KGB in Latvia from 1977-84, and has resisted the Baltic drive for independence. The three Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia have declared independence this year, but Gorbachev has refused to allow them to leave. Pugo, chairman of the Communist Party's Control Committee since 1988 and strong Gorbachev supporter, was appointed to take Bakatin's place by presidential decree, Tass reported. He was named a non-voting member of the Communist Party Politburo in September 1989, but was dropped last July during reforms that drastically reduced the power of the party.

DOC.HEAD: Inhabitants of U.S. Embassy in Kuwait Get Soft Drink Delivery
DOC.TEXT: Ten cases of Pepsi were delivered to the beleagured diplomats at the U.S. embassy in Kuwait, President Bush's national security adviser said Sunday. Brent Scowcroft said U.S. officials still don't know who sent the Pepsi as well as the cigarettes and food that arrived earlier in the week. Bush first mentioned the gifts during a nationally televised news conference on Friday. ``We don't have any better handle on why it's happening,'' Scowcroft said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' ``It obviously isn't being done officially because that embassy is surrounded and has been cut off,'' he said. ``Still no electicity, still no water but some kind of gesture.'' A skeleton crew of diplomats, including Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, and some American citizens have sought refuge at the embassy compound where they have been since Iraq invaded the country on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Burt Lancaster Resting After Stroke
DOC.TEXT: Actor Burt Lancaster was resting at a hospital Sunday after suffering a stroke that left him weak on his right side and made his speech difficult, a hospital official said. ``I can say his condition is basically unchanged,'' nursing supervisor Ardi Smith said Sunday. ``He's having some difficulty with speech. But at the request of the family, I'm not able to say more than that.'' He had been listed in serious condition Friday. At a hospital news conference Saturday, Jack M. Ostrow, Lancaster's friend and financial adviser for 44 years, said he was stable, adding that the 77-year-old actor was in ``fine'' spirits. ``All doctors have advised it will be several days till they're able to give a full report as to the nature and extent of his treatment and recovery,'' Ostrow said. Lancaster has starred in more than 60 movies. He won an Oscar in 1960 for his portrayal of an evangelist in ``Elmer Gantry.'' The actor was visiting a friend at the John Douglas French Center for Alzheimer's Disease Friday when he collapsed in a chair and was taken to the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Warns Soviets Against Sending Troops to Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Sunday issued a strong message to the Soviet Union, warning it not to send troops to the Persian Gulf to help the multinational force. Baghdad also told President Bush not to use proposed talks with Iraq on the gulf crisis ``as a pretext with the American people to justify his aggression against Iraq.'' The statements were among a number of declarations by the official Iraqi News Agency, the Foreign Ministry, state-controlled newspapers and parliament. They gave the impression of growing defiance by Baghdad in the face of mounting international resolve by Washington and its allies to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. The message to Moscow came from the Foreign Ministry, the Iraqi News Agency said. It said it was a response to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's statement Thursday that ``everyone should know that we will not hesitate to use force'' to protect the estimated 3,000 Soviet citizens still in Iraq. The same day, the Soviet Union backed a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing military force to free Kuwait if the Iraqis do not get out by Jan. 15. An unidentified Iraqi Foreign Ministry spokesman said Shevardnadze ``seems to be looking for a pretext to send troops to the region.'' He warned the Kremlin to ``go no further than it has gone so far.'' The statement made no overt threat against the Soviets in Iraq and said they ``enjoy full care and security.'' The Soviets have two warships in the gulf region, but they have not apparently taken part in the U.S.-led multinational naval force blockade of Iraq. The Kremlin has said it would not become militarily involved unless its forces were under U.N. command. Moscow has a friendship treaty with Baghdad and was its main arms supplier during the 1980-88 war with Iran. The Soviets have played a key mediation role in the crisis, but have also become impatient with Saddam's refusal to withdraw from Kuwait. The comments by Iraqi officials came as a Soviet envoy met with senior Iraqi officials Sunday seeking the release of Soviet citizens, mainly oil specialists and technicians. There were about 10,000 Soviets, including several hundred military advisers, in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. Most have been allowed to leave in groups. Iraq has blamed ``misunderstandings and bureaucracy'' for the delays in evacuating the remainder. Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council said Saturday it accepted Bush's offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad for talks on the gulf crisis. But it said the talks must include the issue of Israel's occupation of Arab land. The Iraqis have repeatedly linked their occupation of Kuwait with the ``Palestine issue,'' but the Americans have rejected that linkage. First Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yasin Ramadan said Sunday that the Bush administration's desire for talks ``indicates a retreat after grasping that world and Arab public opinion uncovered its misleading behavior for achieving its own interests,'' the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The Al-Qadissiyah newspaper stressed that Iraq was not interested in a ``pro-forma meeting, which Bush needs to overcome his domestic problems and which he might use as a new pretext with the American people to justify his aggression against Iraq.'' Bush's overture to Iraq was widely seen as a move to placate Congressional critics and others counseling against military action that could result in thousands of casualties and create political turbulence in the Middle East. Bush doesn't appear to have any formula to offer Iraq to induce it to quit Kuwait and has repeatedly stressed that there is nothing to negotiate. He said Friday that no ``big results'' should be expected from any talks with Iraq. More than 350,000 troops are in the Persian Gulf as part of the US.-led multinational force. American troops, now numbering more 240,000, are expected to swell to around 400,000 by next month.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Weather Service Fails On Severe Weather Spotting
DOC.TEXT: The National Weather Service has fallen short of its mission to warn the public of savage weather that claims more than 400 lives and causes $6 billion in damage every year, a newspaper reported Sunday. The federal agency misses two-thirds of all tornadoes, three-fifths of all flash floods and 40 percent of severe thunderstorms every year, The Plain Dealer reported. Severe storms strike without warning from the weather service more than 4,000 times and without a preliminary ``watch'' 5,000 times each year. Government forecasters failed to issue warnings in two of this year's most deadly storms in the Midwest - a flash flood in Shadyside in June that killed 26 people and tornadoes in northern Illinois in August that left 29 people dead. For every five floods that cause at least $500,000 in damage, three occur without any warning, the newspaper said. The newspaper said its investigation was based on an analysis of weather service internal computer records and other data, including statistics assembled from 1987 to 1989 by the Services Evaluation Branch, which grades forecasting offices and trains personnel for the NWS Office of Meteorology. For the last eight years, the agency's own investigations of disaster foul-ups repeatedly have cited the same causes: A shortage of forecasters, obsolete equipment, poor communications and, in some cases, incompetence. ``As I look through status reports on existing systems, I don't have a month go by in which we don't have at least a half a dozen radars around the country out for a significant period of time ... because of basic components,'' weather service Director Elbert W. Friday Jr. told the newspaper. He offered little hope for quick improvement. ``We're keeping (the weather service) tied together now ith the proverbial baling wire and chewing gum,'' he said. The weather service budget has had only slight budget increases in recent years, and in some spending categories, cuts have resulted in sharp personnel cutbacks. The current $330 million operating budget gives the weather service the same buying power it had in the 1960s. Experts say that advances in technology allow forecasters to alert the public in advance of all severe thunderstorms, and nearly all floods and large tornadoes, the newspaper said. Friday acknowledged that despite antiquated equipment that is not to be replaced until 1995, weather offices should be able to issue warnings for 70 percent to 75 percent of all severe storms, including tornadoes, thunderstorms and flash floods. Data from the Services Evaluation Branch shows that no warnings were issued for 68 percent of all tornadoes and 64 percent of all flash floods from 1987 to 1989. Fifty-one percent of all flash flood warnings were issued after the floods began. Forecasters failed to warn of 17 out of 27 killer floods. Four of every five tornado warnings and six of every 10 flash-flood warnings were false alarms. Even when tornado warnings were issued, the public had only an average seven to 10 minutes to get to safety, the figures showed. ``We're not doing too well,'' said meteorologist Bill Lerner, one of the weather service's official scorekeepers in the Services Evaluation Branch. The weather service has, however, succeeded in the past. In February 1982, weather service forecasters in Fort Wayne, Ind., urged the mayor to prepare emergency shelters and fill sandbags. Seventeen days later, they predicted a flood within 24 hours and issued an official warning. Floods struck as predicted, killing 12. But 15,000 people had moved to shelters and local officials credited the forecasters with saving the city. In addition, some of the service's 249 forecasting offices do better than others, the newspaper said. In Shreveport, La., forecasters have accurately issued warnings for more than 80 percent of all storms there, said chief forecaster Ernest Ethridge. By contrast, Chicago's weather office, which failed to warn of the Aug. 28 tornado that killed 29 people, has the worst record in the nation, the newspaper said. In the last three years, it has issued warnings for only 24 percent of all severe storms in its jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: EEOC To Accept `Tester' Complaints of Job Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Sunday the federal government will begin prosecuting job discrimination cases in which individuals used as ``testers'' by civil rights groups charge they have been illegally denied employment. The new policy extends the use of testers - long a tactic in housing discrimination suits - to the federal employment bias arena for the first time. ``It's used in housing cases and used by other state agencies, and I couldn't see why it couldn't be used by the commission,'' Evan J. Kemp Jr., chairman of the EEOC, said in a telephone interview. ``Testers'' - or individuals from minority and women's groups who historically have been victims of discrimination - have posed as renters or home buyers to win housing discrimination suits. The Supreme Court in 1982 said such activities were legal even if the testers did not intend to rent or buy. However, the government never has used the testimony of testers to prosecute job discrimination cases. Kemp said the new commission policy, announced Friday, would address one of the ``weaknesses'' of the EEOC system. ``People that apply for a job in answer to a newspaper ad can be discriminated against and they won't know it,'' under current circumstances, Kemp said. The EEOC chairman said he was confident his agency has the legal authority to bring the cases because the ``courts address this all the time and make a determination whether an employer has discriminated or not.'' Representatives of the business community could not be reached for comment Sunday on the new policy. But Stephen Bokat of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce told The Washington Post that ``proving the case'' of job bias against an employment tester would be ``infinitely more difficult than it is in the housing context.'' In housing the ``only issue is whether someone is financially capable of paying the rent on the property or buying a piece of property,'' Bokat was quoted as saying in Sunday's editions of the newspaper. In job testing cases, ``there are all sorts of things, how articulate the person is ... lots more subjective considerations that go into a decision,'' Bokat said. Kemp admitted there may be some difficulties in implementing the policy and said his agency was still deciding ``how we're going to work it.'' There are no current tests set up, Kemp said, but the agency would initiate proceedings on charges brought by civil rights and community groups. Kemp said the policy was prompted by the case brought by city and state authorities against a temporary employment agency in New York City after a report on CBS-TV's ``60 Minutes'' program showing the use of testers. Kemp said he expects the policy to come up during previously scheduled meetings with representatives of several women's groups on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Sweethearts Wed After 70-Year Misunderstanding
DOC.TEXT: Two sweethearts have married after mending a disagreement that kept them apart for almost 70 years. Charles Jones and Thelma Colvin dated as teen-agers in the 1920s, but a spat at a street party in Springfield ended their romance - temporarily. Jones broke off a two-year relationship with Colvin after seeing her strolling with another man, despite her protests of innocence. When they met again last fall, both widowed, the dispute no longer mattered. They got married Thursday in Decatur's Macon County Courthouse. ``I still think she was seeing that other guy,'' Jones, 84, joked. His bride, 85, insisted she wasn't. ``I just happened to meet a chum I had known in school while I was out that evening,'' she said. ``There was nothing in it, but Charles didn't believe me.''
