DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishops To Attack Centuries Of Anti-Semitism In Poland
DOC.TEXT: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops will for the first time issue a pastoral letter attacking the anti-Semitism that has darkened the country's name for centuries. The letter, to be read at all Masses on Sunday, Jan. 20, is the most explicit statement on Catholic-Jewish relations ever issued by the Polish church. The move comes as anti-Semitism is reappearing in the nation's political life in the post-Communist era. It also follows criticism from international Jewish groups who say they are dismayed by church foot-dragging and concerned about whether its January statement will condemn specific anti-Semitic incidents. The Episcopate Commission for Dialogue with Judaism told the official PAP news agency Saturday that the pastoral letter expresses ``regret over any instances of anti-Semitism on Polish soil.'' It said the letter recalls Polish-born Pope John Paul II's teaching that anti-Semitism contradicts Christian values. The letter, which caps two years of work by the commission and is endorsed by the bishop's council, can be expected to carry enormous weight among Poles, 93 percent of whom consider themselves Catholic. The text was not disclosed. But the Rev. Stanislaw Musial, the commission secretary, recently issued the first statement by a ranking church official on Polish Catholic culpability in the Nazi extermination of 3 million Polish Jews during World War II. He also spoke of discrimination in Poland before and after the war. ``For every Pole of Christian faith who did not stretch his helpful hand to you in those days and after ... who betrayed you to the Nazis ... who tried to enrich himself on your fear and loneliness, for all these, we beg your pardon,'' the priest wrote in the influential Catholic Tygodnik Powszechny weekly. Sources in Poland's religious communities acknowledged there was disagreement among the bishops about how strong a statement to issue. Jewish groups generally praised the latest plans, but questioned whether they are enough. ``I am very glad something like this will be done, and I hope it will be sufficiently specific to hit the consciences of many of the churchgoers,'' said Stanislaw Krajewski, representative of the American Jewish Congress in Poland and a leader of its tiny Jewish community. ``But I really hope that some specific things are said ... that `Jew' is used as a word of abuse more generally ... and that the unfortunate issue of who is Jewish ... was so heavily used during the presidential campaign.'' During the current presidential campaign, rumors circulated that the Catholic Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was Jewish or that Jews dominated his government. Mazowiecki's defeat in the first round of voting Nov. 25 was attributed mainly to discontent with economic reforms, however. The American Jewish Congress in mid-November questioned the delay in issuing the Catholic document and said ``the current resurgence of anti-Semitism in Poland has not been sufficiently addressed by the church.'' Jews have lived in Poland since the 13th century. In the Middle Ages, the country was a haven for some Jews fleeing persecution elsewhere in Europe, although even then they suffered widespread discrimination. Poland's 3.5 million Jews were one-tenth of the population in 1939. Only about 500,000 survived the war. Afterward, some were threatened and even killed when coming home to recover family property. Waves of emigration, including a 1968 Communist-backed purge, have reduced the Jewish population to a few thousand mostly elderly people.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Officials Seek Solution to Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with new quotes, no progress in agricultural talks; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Trade ministers searched on Sunday for an 11th-hour miracle to rescue stalled free trade talks but failed to make any progress on the biggest stumbling block: how to reduce costly farm subsidies. There was some progress reported on another dispute involving removing barriers to trade in financial services. But a series of meetings on the agriculture question yielded no results. The activity came as delegates from 107 nations prepared to open five days of formal negotiations Monday in hopes of completing a four-year effort to overhaul the world trading system. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the nation where they began in 1986, were being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett, chairman of the Cairns Group of 14 major farm-exporting countries, said the entire bargaining effort was ``in deep crisis.'' He said what happens over the next 48 hours would likely decide whether the negotiations could succeed. ``There is a general recognition that agriculture is at the heart of the crisis ... and that blockage is poisoning other parts of the negotiations,'' he told reporters. The Cairns Group, supported by the United States, is attempting to scale back agriculture subsidies, which cost consumers and taxpayers $250 billion annually. However, the 12-nation European Community and Japan have resisted, contending the measures go too far and would cause massive political unrest among farm groups in their nations. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter held what he termed ``sparring'' sessions with both Ray MacSharry, the EC's agriculture chief, and Japanese Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto. He said that neither the Europeans nor the Japanese were signalling any willingness to compromise. ``Unless both Japan and the European Community begin to demonstrate greater commitment to trade liberalization in agriculture, I see no way of reaching'' an overall Uruguay Round agreement, Yeutter said. The United States and the Cairns Group are pushing a proposal that would cut export subsidies by 90 percent, while reducing internal farm support payments and barriers to farm imports by 75 percent. The United States has also been lobbying heavily to get Japan to show good faith in the farm area by removing its ban on the import of rice, a barrier that forces Japanese consumers to pay seven times the world market price. Without an agreement in agriculture, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Third World nations would walk away from the bargaining table, dooming the most ambitious reform effort in 43 years. On another dispute, officials reported some progress Sunday in an effort to get countries to extend the GATT coverage to trade in service industries such as banking and insurance. Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie told reporters that Canada, with the support of several other countries, would put forward a proposal Monday to address removing barriers in financial services. He said the measure had the support of both the United States and the EC. But with just five days to go until the negotiations are scheduled to conclude Friday, there were still many blank spaces in the draft 291-page agreement, prompting a growing sense of failure. ``We are going to do our best to try to make it work, but it is going to take an 11th-hour miracle,'' said U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, one of four members of President Bush's Cabinet in Brussels for the negotiations. This is the eighth round of negotiations aimed at lowering tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade. The negotiators are also attempting to extend GATT's rules to trade in services as well as writing rules to govern the theft on intellectual property rights, principally by Third World nations. Such thefts of copyrights and patents cost American businesses an estimated $60 billion annually. In all, 107 nations from Austria to Zimbabwe are involved in the negotiations, either as full-fledged members of GATT or observers, a category that includes China.

DOC.HEAD: American Donations of Food and Medical Supplies Arrive in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: ``To the Soviet people from the people of the United States - with love,'' read the banners on 40 tons of donated food and medical supplies that arrived in Moscow Sunday. It was the first of many shipments planned by the Connecticut-based aid organization, AmeriCares, to help relieve Soviet citizens faced with barren grocery shelves and severe shortages of imported medicines. Soviet television showed soldiers and students unloading cartons of medical supplies from the Southern Air Transport cargo plane. Dr. Vasily Drozdov, head of the Republican Children's Clinic, said the medicine, for children under the age of three, arrived at his hospital late Sunday. The Soviet Union's chronic shortages of food and medicine have worsened dramatically this winter. Consumers must wait in long lines - often for as long as three hours - for basics such as butter. Sometimes, pushing and shoving breaks out over a scarce item. The shortages are caused in part by the country's transition from a centralized planning system to a free market, which has not yet taken hold. The centralized distribution system is breaking down in anticipation of changes. A shortage of foreign currency that forced a cut in imports earlier this year has also caused shortages, although President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has now won promises of billions of dollars of new credits and aid from abroad. In addition, the country doesn't have enough rail cars or refrigerated trucks to transport food from the fields to markets, nor are there sufficient storage facilities. Theft and diversion to the black market is rampant. Thus, despite normal levels of food production and a spectacular grain crop, food is not reaching consumers at the usual subsidized prices. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov gave a televised address after the evening news Sunday, calling on people to work together to overcome the food crisis. ``Everyone is pulling in different directions,'' he said, referring to individual republics and regions that are refusing to sell their food to other districts. Soviet television said AmeriCares plans to send 450 tons of food and medicine. AmeriCares representative Ty Cordova said he would stay and supervise up to the last shipment to ensure the supplies are not lost in the black market - or in the constant breakdowns of the Soviet cargo transport system. Drozdov said his clinic so far had received only medicine, and no food. ``We don't really need food at the moment. Nutrition at the clinic is all right,'' he said. Doctors from the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City traveled with the AmeriCares staffers and will discuss further supply needs with Soviet medical specialists. AmeriCares representatives in the United States said an 80,000-pound shipment of food and medical supplies was to be given to the clinic and two orphanages in Moscow. Another 250,000 pounds of supplies is scheduled to be sent to the Soviet Union on Dec. 26, a spokesman for AmeriCares said Saturday. Since the Armenian earthquake two years ago, AmeriCares has sent at least 15 shipments of aid to the Soviet Union. Another planeload of food arrived from Germany on Friday for distribution among hospitals and orphanages. Italy and Austria have also promised food and medical supplies.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS JAKARTA, Indonesia-dated item in AM-People, a0700, to RESTORE dropped word `said' in 6th graf, `Bali Gov...'.
DOC.TEXT: A Hindu leader in Bali says British rock singer Mick Jagger's recent wedding to longtime girlfriend Jerry Hall was illegal and merely imitated parts of a traditional Balinese wedding ceremony. I Wayan Surpha, chairman of the Indonesian Hinduism Association in Bali's capital of Denpasar, said Jagger has not yet met conditions to be a follower of Hinduism, the official Antara news agency reported Saturday. Jagger, 47, and Hall, a 34-year-old model from Texas, married Nov. 21 in Bali. Ida Pedanda Sukawati, a Hindu priest, said he presided over the ceremony, which included a rite signifying entrance into Hinduism, the agency reported. The couple also signed a statement indicating they had converted. But Surpha objected, saying, ``It should not be so easy to hold such ceremony.'' Bali Gov. Ida Bagus Mantra also said traditional weddings ``should not be given too easily'' to foreigners vacationing in Bali, the agency reported. Bali is one of the islands that make up Indonesia. Jagger publicist Lisa Somes did not immediately return a telephone message left Sunday with an answering service for Rogers & Cowan, a New York public relations firm with which she works.

DOC.HEAD: More Protesters Hit Streets in Bangladesh, Dozens Reported Killed
DOC.TEXT: More anti-government protesters poured into the streets Sunday, and an opposition leader said dozens of people were killed and thousands wounded since emergency rules were decreed five days earlier. The new protests broke out when the government of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad relaxed a curfew for 12 hours. About 500 university teachers announced they were quitting their jobs to protest the emergency orders suspending civil liberties. The Interior Ministry said security forces broke up ``an unruly mob'' that tried to ransack stores and burn vehicles in Dhaka's maintain downtown shopping area. No details were given. But in general, the law-and-order situation was improving, the ministry claimed in a news release. After curfew was re-imposed at sundown Sunday, paramilitary troops in another part of the capital were seen removing the body of a young man in civilian clothing. Bullet wounds were visible on his body, but the circumstances of his death could not be ascertained, according to passerby who spoke on condition of anonymity. State-run television said curfew would be lifted for 15 hours on Monday, from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. The government has gradually been extending the number of hours people are allowed to leave their homes. The government eased press censorship for international news agencies but cautioned correspondents against ``misreporting.'' Ershad, who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982, imposed emergency rule in an effort to quell six weeks of unrest led by university students and the two chief opposition parties. The leader of the opposition Awami League, Sheik Hasina, said Sunday in a statement that 17 people were killed in various clashes around the country on Saturday. She said that brought the death toll to 75 since emergency rules went into effect Tuesday night. About 3,000 people have been wounded, she said. Two leaders of her party were arrested on Sunday, she said in a written statement. She said that brings the number of people arrested during the state of emergency to 5,000. The government has said only six people have been killed since the emergency was imposed. In the past, some opposition claims have been exaggerated, while some government counts have been understated. No independent verification of their claims was possible. About 1,000 lawyers, artists, students and journalists assembled in front of National Press Club, shouting ``Ershad must quit!'' ``We don't want emergency!'' and ``Down with press censorship!'' More than 100 policemen in riot gear watched but did not intervene. The gathering broke up peacefully. In Chittagong, a port city 125 miles southeast of Dhaka, 300 professors and lecturers at Chittagong University announced their resignations. Another 200 doctors and teachers at the Sir Salimulla Medical College in Dhaka also said they were quitting, effective Monday, according to a statement from the students union. Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general, told the paramilitary Bangladesh Rifles that the opposition campaign has ``no political objective and it is aimed at destroying the national economy.'' Part of his speech was shown on state-run television Sunday. The opposition alliance called for a nationwide transportation strike starting Tuesday. They also called for the creation of People's Action Committees in cities and villages to resist the government and its supporters. The opposition is demanding that Ershad step down and allow a caretaker government to supervise free elections. They claim that previous elections held since Ershad took power were rigged.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Defends Hostage-Holding, Says He's Open to Talks
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein said in a television interview aired Sunday that he believes the chances of war in the Persian Gulf stand at ``fifty-fifty,'' but that he is open to talks. The Iraqi leader also said Iraq does not posses nuclear arms, and he defended the holding of foreign hostages. The interview, with the French network Antenne 2, was the first Saddam has granted to a foreign television network since the U.N. Security Council last week adopted a resolution authorizing force against Iraq if its troops remained in Kuwait as of Jan. 15. The Iraqi president repeatedly refused to respond to questions about a possible Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, which his forces have occupied since Aug. 2. But in the interview, taped in Baghdad Saturday, Saddam said he was ready to talk with U.S. officials if they came ``in a spirit of dialogue'' and did not set preconditions. He said the holding of an estimated 3,000 Western hostages was ``one of the means that we think is capable of preventing war.'' He said if the United States wanted the hostages freed, it should pledge that it will not resort to force prior to March 25. The Iraqi president had offered earlier to free all the hostages between Christmas and March 25 if nothing happens to mar ``the atmosphere of peace.'' The Antenne 2 interviewer asked Saddam about the chances of war in the region. ``Fifty-fifty,'' the Iraqi leader replied. Elaborating on that, he cited the U.S. offer to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad for talks. ``If they want to make this meeting a raal path toward dialogue, then we are closer to peace,'' he said. ``But if they want to make this meeting nothing other than a formal exhibition for the American Congress, the American people or international public opinion, simply to give themselves good conscience to say, `There, we've tried to dialogue with Iraq, without Iraq renouncing its positions' - in that case, we're closer to war.'' Saddam denied that his government possessed nuclear weapons, but said he would let the world know if that were the case. ``But we don't possess nuclear arms,'' he said. U.S. officials have raised the possibility of Iraq developing nuclear capability in coming years, and said that would be one reason to move against Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Critical Round Of U.S. Bases Talks This Week in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Philippine negotiators will tackle the difficult issue of compensation when they resume talks this week on the future of six American military bases in this country. In preparation for the talks, which Filipino sources say will resume Tuesday, U.S. officials restricted the movements of the 40,000 U.S. troops, Pentagon civilians and military dependents living here. Last May, Communist rebels killed two U.S. airmen near Clark Air Base on the eve of an opening round of talks. Despite a standing threat from the New People's Army, there were no attacks against Americans during later sessions in September and November. At issue in the talks is the future of Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations the Americans hold under an agreement that expires in September. Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus, the chief Philippine negotiator, has demanded Philippine control over Clark and the smaller bases next year. But the government has left open the possibility of extending the U.S. stay at Subic, considered the most strategic installation, for 5-7 years. Filipino officials have said they might let the Americans keep access to Clark on a commercial basis. Chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage has acknowledged the American military presence will be scaled down under any new agreement. But U.S. officials would like a phasedown period to vacate the bases, followed by an arrangement under which the Americans maintain a residual presence. Philippine officials say the upcoming round will discuss how much the Americans will pay for use of the facilities. U.S. sources familiar with the talks say the Philippine panel has so far not raised the compensation issue or given any indication of what it considers an acceptable figure. In 1988, the Reagan Administration agreed to seek $960 million in aid over two years for use of the bases through 1991. But last year, Congress cut the Bush Administration's aid request for the Philippines, provoking charges that the United States had reneged on its pledge. The Philippines would like the new agrement to include iron-clad guarantees of aid. American officials have consistently refused to go beyond a pledge to exert their ``best efforts'' to meet aid targets. ``This time we are not talking about an executive agreement but a treaty, and the best efforts device is not applicable,'' Manglapus said in a recent interview. An acceptable compensation arrangement is considered critical to prospects for approval of the new agreement in the Philippine Senate. Under the 1987 Constitution, any new agreement must be covered within a formal treaty ratified by two-thirds of the 23-member Philippine Senate. Previously, the status of U.S. bases was formalized under an executive agreement between chief executives of the two countries. Last week, an informal survey conducted by Senate President Jovito Salonga found 12 senators opposed to allowing the Americans to stay beyond the September deadline. That would be enough to defeat any agreement allowing U.S. forces to remain. But diplomatic observers believe an acceptable compensation package, perhaps including trade concessions rather than cash, would sway enough senators to win agreement. Compensation has become all the more urgent for the Philippines because of the country's economic crisis, worsened by the rise in world petroleum prices and the effects of an earthquake that killed nearly 1,700 people last July. Finance Secretary Jesus Estanislao and others fear that the Americans would not exert their influence with the International Monetary Fund and other lending institutions on behalf of this country if no agreement on the bases can be reached. In addition, recent surveys show growing pro-bases sentiment among the 61 million Filipinos. If the final package appears favorable to the Philippines, some senators may switch their stand rather than face the electorate in the 1992 elections after voting to shut down the installations.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Reserves Bolster Regular Corps
With AM-Gulf Rdp
LaserPhoto RA1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Marine reservists uprooted from their homes and families accepted their pending participation in Operation Desert Shield with a mixture of resignation and understanding. ``We all signed up for it and now we've got to do it,'' said 22-year-old Lance Cpl. Kevin Nobis of Waterloo, Iowa. Between 10,000 and 12,000 of the 43,000 Marine Corps reservists in the United States will call this eastern North Carolina base home during an intense training period before their likely deployment to the Middle East later this month, said Lejeune spokesman Maj. Jay Farrar. The first group arrived Nov. 26, and the Camp Lejeune Military Processing Center has inoculated, shaved, shorn and dog-tagged about 1,000 a day since. ``This event is brought to you by Saddam Hussein,'' reads a sign inside the center just above a cartoon depicting the Iraq leader in a gun sight. ``We sent out roughly 10,000 Marines when this began,'' Farrar said. ``Now we're bringing that many through again.'' About 80 percent of the Marine reserves called to action will join with active duty troops for two to four weeks' training. ``People think the reserves are just weekend warriors, but we really train hard and we know how to do the job. We just need some practice,'' Lance Cpl. Richard Nordenbrook, 21, of Fairfax, Va., said Sunday at an anti-tank missile practice range. ``People always talk about them being weekend warriors,'' said active duty Marine Lt. Mike Nosbisch, 24, of Buffalo, N.Y. ``But they've got a mission here, too, and that mission is to go to war. ``Whether or not people want to hear that, that's what it is.'' About 50 men trained with live missiles for the first time since the reservists arrived a week ago. As the reserves sat nearby observing the exercise, mortar shells exploded about 1,000 meters out into the practice range providing a smoke screen as two armored trucks carrying anti-tank TOW missiles raced out of hiding and into position. The reservists sat out of the action, but if the Camp Lejeune unit goes to Saudi Arabia, their newest members will go right along with them. ``If my country needs me then I'm here,'' said Nordenbrook. ``None of the active duty troops want to go either, but none of us are complaining.''

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Use Waiting Ladders in Escape
DOC.TEXT: Six inmates escaped from jail by climbing ladders construction workers left standing against a wall, authorities said. Four of the men were still at large Sunday, said Contra Costa County Sheriff's Sgt. Hal Rogers. ``Any felon should be considered dangerous, but these men were not in for such violent crimes as homicide or rape,'' Rogers said. ``They were sentenced for things like robbery or burglary.'' The six escaped Saturday night, while other inmates set off fire alarms to distract guards. The fugitives knocked out the window of a door leading to a courtyard with a desk, said Rogers. ``The construction people working in that section forgot to put away the ladders and they just climbed them,'' he said. Two of the men were captured shortly after the escape was discovered just after midnight.

DOC.HEAD: Filipinos Tell Of Food Shortages In Iraq and Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Filipinos who arrived from Iraq and Kuwait on Sunday said Iraqi soldiers are looting grocery stores and homes, and even scavenging for scraps from departing foreigners. They also told of long lines for food and sky-high food prices. They said food prices in Baghdad had jumped ten-fold because of the United Nations sanctions imposed following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some of the 437 Filipinos, who arrived in Manila on a flight from Basra, Iraq, also said Iraqi soldiers were still looting groceries and homes in occupied Kuwait. ``There's so much hunger there,'' Lorenza Panaranda, 30, said of conditions in Basra, Iraq's second largest city. ``When we threw away our leftovers, about 10 Iraqis scrambled over our leftovers in the trashcan at the airport. We left whatever food we had with them.'' Gregorio Neri, an Arabic-speaking mechanic who acted as interpreter for the group in Iraq, said consumers in Basra stand in line for up to four hours to buy a single loaf of bread. ``The life of the Iraqis now is hard,'' he said. ``Filipino lives may be difficult, but theirs is miserable. I would never change places.'' Willie Leola said that when his group, which included five infants, cleared customs at Basra airport, customs guards asked for their leftover baby formula. The Filipinos arrived aboard an Iraqi Airways jet on a flight paid for by the International Organization of Migration. An estimated 90,000 Filipinos were working in Kuwait and Iraq before the Iraqi invasion. Miss Panaranda, who had worked as a sales clerk in Kuwait, said she went to Baghdad last month and then to Basra for the flight. She said shoopers waited for hours to buy limited supplies of food in Baghdad. ``There were queues for food all over,'' she said. ``Instead of rice, they eat gruel made of corn.'' She said that in one neighborhood, shoppers were limited to five kilos of rice per month. Conchita Balisi, 27, a former governess in Kuwait, said most groceries are closed in the occupied city. ``Some Kuwaitis go to Saudi Arabia to buy food and then sell it back in Kuwait,'' she said. Lisa Santuyo, a maid in Kuwait, said Iraqi soldiers were looting homes and shops of food, appliances and other goods to ship back to Iraq. ``At night, there is shooting,'' she said. ``Families would then pray as they wept. Soldiers go to houses and Kuwaitis are afraid, especially if Iraqi soldiers find out they have relatives in the army.''

DOC.HEAD: Marines Hold Amphibious Exercise
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines began a four-day amphibious exercise in the Persian Gulf, military officials said Sunday. They refused to say whether the maneuvers were a practice invasion of Kuwait. Few details were provided about the exercise. Military officials refused to disclose the exact location of the practice landings, the number of Marines involved or whether forces from other countries were taking part. But they indicated that U.S. warplanes were taking part. The maneuvers, codenamed Amphibex, are the fourth amphibious exercise since Operation Desert Shield began in early August following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The military said elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and the Navy's Amphibious Task Group Two were taking part. The exercise is smaller than maneuvers last month, codenamed Imminent Thunder. That six-day exercise involved thousands of Marines, sailors and airmen and was described as the biggest since the U.S. deployment began. Saudi Arabian forces participated and British and Saudi combat aircraft joined American Air Force and Marine squadrons mustered for the exercise. Unlike in Imminent Thunder, the forces taking part in Amphibex are allowed to fire their weapons in the air and on the ground, officials reported. The Marines are also slated to use helicopters and hovercraft in the latest exercise, scheduled to end Wednesday. Officials declined comment when asked whether Amphibex is a rehearsal for an actual landing in Kuwait. There are more than 240,000 U.S. military personnel deployed in Desert Shield. Another 200,000 more are en route or being sent soon. Desert Shield's amphibious capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigades. They make up the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, the largest Marine force assembled since the Vietnam War. An additional amphibious group comprising the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force from Camp Lejeune, N.C., will be deployed by mid-January. It has roughly 45,000 men.

DOC.HEAD: Drills, Exodus Highlight Quake Watch
DOC.TEXT: The earth stood still Sunday, as usual. The only thing moving was the stream of jumpy residents fleeing in fear of an earthquake. New Mexico scientist Iben Browning projected a 50-50 chance of a major temblor along the New Madrid fault for the five days that began Saturday. The fault's southern end is under this town of about 3,200 people. It runs northeast to Cairo, Ill. Browning, 72, bases his theory on the gravitational pull of the sun and moon, which he says will be particularly strong during the period. On the basis of that, dozens of people have packed their things and left town. Scientists have scoffed at his projection. But these same scientists say an earthquake is likely someday. So even skeptical residents, like convenience store cashier Rheba Womack, aren't taking any chances. ``If this doesn't happen, I don't want to hear anything else about earthquakes,'' Mrs. Womack said. A few hours later, on Saturday night, Mrs. Womack and her husband, Scott, left town, joining the temporary migration. Those who stayed prayed. ``Bless all of us, oh Father, that are upset about the earthquake,'' said Ira Whitfield when he oened Sunday school at St. John Missionary Baptist Church. Church Deacon Sterling Ivy said he had expected the crowd to be smaller than usual. It was, what with some people suddenly out of town and others afraid to leave their houses. The same concern has closed schools in parts of Tennessee, Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky and Illinois for a few days early this week. Judy Byrd of Evansville, Ind., isn't waiting for local school administrators to decide. Though she said she doesn't believe earthquakes can be projected, her 11-year-old son won't be in school Monday. ``He asked me if he could stay home,'' Mrs. Byrd said. ``At this age, they really worry about everything. War. An earthquake. Water. The environment. I figured if he really was that worried about it, it should be up to him.'' Other people were looking for a more precise warning. In Illinois' St. Clair County, residents were watching cats, dogs and cows for signs of nervousness. ``If we notice any exceptional behavior, we will not hold school Monday,'' said Superintendent Bill Gullick of the county's Marissa Community Unit School District 40. The Chinese have been using that method to anticipate earthquakes for more than 1,000 years, Gullick said. Some people here have chosen to stay put. What they're afraid of, they say, is worse than any earthquake: looters and bad publicity for the town. Police Officer Jay Woods said looting hasn't been a problem, especially with a lot of people gone. ``I stopped a lady for speeding last night, and she said, `Officer, I'm just in a hurry to get through Marked Tree.''' Woods couldn't bring himself to write her a ticket, he said. While residents wrestled with their anxieties about whether to stay or go, emergency experts in Arkansas were busy Sunday planning for an earthquake they could believe in. In an earthquake disaster drill planned long before Browning's projection, officials were assessing an imaginary toll of death and destruction from a hypothetical earthquake. On paper, the quake laid waste to much of the northeastern part of the state. The drill, involving the Arkansas National Guard and other state and federal agencies, was based on a worst-case scenario of an earthquake measuring 7.6 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. The make-believe quake hit Friday. By Sunday, according to the drill's script, the toll in eastern Arkansas had reached 4,950 dead, 25,097 seriously injured and 98,020 left homeless. ``Realistically we would still be in a search and rescue mode,'' said Gary Talley of the Arkansas Office of Emergency Services, which coordinated the drill.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Prime Minister, Defeated for President, Founds New Party
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki on Sunday urged supporters of his failed presidential bid to vote for Lech Walesa, but called for creation of a new political party to oppose the Solidarity leader in the future. ``In the face of the irresponsibility that may endanger Poland and everything we have been struggling for 10 years, we should cast our ballots in favor of Mr. Walesa,'' said Mazowiecki at the founding of the new Union of Polish Democracy. The prime minister referred to the campaign of Stanislaw Tyminski, the wealthy emigre who came from obscurity to reach the presidential runoff election on Sunday, Dec. 9. ``This does not mean an agreement with his vision of democracy in Poland and his style of action,'' Mazowiecki said of Walesa. Mazowiecki was an adviser of Walesa's for nine years until becoming the East Bloc's first non-Communist prime minister in August 1989. Mazowiecki has said he will leave office when the new president is chosen. Despite his third-place showing in the first round of the presidential elections Nov. 25, the prime minister received a hero's welcome from about 1,000 supporters at Warsaw University on Sunday. He was cheered for five minutes in the crowded hall when he appeared, and frequently was interrupted by applause as he spoke to the audience that included members of his election campaign committees. ``We didn't win,'' Mazowiecki said. ``But our rationales exist and are deeply rooted in the society. Our most important task today is to keep together those millions of friends and to create a political formation. I am convinced that we will ... be a key element on the Polish political scene.'' The party later was officially founded by acclamation by members of Mazowiecki's campaign committees, and representatives of two other pro-Mazowiecki groups present: the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action and the Forum of the Democratic Right. Meanwhile, Walesa adviser Zdzislaw Najder, addressing a conference of local Citizens Committees, criticized Mazowiecki's camp for having denigrated the Solidarity leader as ``unpredictable and unsteerable'' in the first round. In other political developments, Walesa remained in Warsaw after a Saturday evening news conference with Tyminski and planned to attend the funeral of a Roman Catholic bishop. Tyminski scheduled an evening rally in the northeastern city of Bialystok. Earlier, Tyminski went to the 10th anniversary gathering of the Communist-backed Union of Rural Youth in Warsaw. Among guests at the gathering was Waldemar Swirgon, a former Central Committee secretary and leader of the main Communist youth organizations in the late 1970s and 1980s, the official PAP news agency reported. Tyminski has been criticized for ties to the former Communist elite in Poland. Walesa has termed his candidacy an attempted ``counter-revolution,'' but Tyminski says he accepts support from various quarters. A scheduled nationally televised debate between Walesa and Tyminski on Sunday night did not take place. Tyminski had insisted it be postponed until Thursday, and did not appear at the Warsaw television studio.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Midwest, Rain Dampens South
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell Sunday on the country's northern midsection and rained farther south. Upper Michigan, central North Dakota, central and southern Nebraska, northeastern Missouri, west-central Illinois, central Colorado, southeastern Wyoming and central Montana got snow. Fort Collins, Colo., was thrashed by winds gusting to 60 mph., the National Weather Service said. Rain came to west-central Missouri and poured across northeastern and east-central Illinois, north-central and southern Kentucky, Tennessee, northern Alabama, eastern and southwestern Mississippi, southeastern Louisiana and south-central Arkansas. Rain was also scattered in northwestern Washington state. And occasional thundershowers intensified the rain that fell across north central and from central Texas to south central Texas. The morning low in the Lower 48 was 18 degrees below zero at International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 5 degrees at Grand Rapids, Mich., to 88 at Harlingen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Five Students Trapped in Cave By Flood Waters Emerge Unscathed
DOC.TEXT: Five college students were surprised, shivering and shaking when they emerged unscathed after being trapped by a flash flood for more than seven hours in the depths of a mile-long cave. ``We were all very scared,'' Scott Baisch, a senior at Syracuse University, said Sunday. ``We thought we would die there.'' Baisch and four companions had entered Onesquethaw Cave, located in an isolated area about 10 miles southwest of Albany, about 2 p.m. Saturday. They became trapped a little more than two hours later when a beaver dam on a tiny lake about three miles from the cave entrance burst, sending a torrent of water cascading down a stream bed and into the 50-foot-deep cave. The cave began to flood when the three men and two women were about three-quarters of the way in. The students had last been seen entering the cave early Saturday afternoon by another party of spelunkers from Massachusetts, who alerted police after the dam burst. State police divers and other rescuers entered the cave early Saturday evening, but were turned back by high water after exploring nearly 500 feet. Divers and experienced spelunkers eventually made it in as far as 850 feet, but the searches were called off temporarily about 9 p.m. while authorities worked feverishly to shore up the dam with shale to prevent it from collapsing again. ``We all thought we were going to drown,'' said Lynn Cowan, a student at Columbia University who said she's through spelunking. ``At first I just panicked. I had never really considered that I could die this young.'' Besides Baisch and Cowan, the group consisted of Laura Selicaro and Nicholas Springer, both Syracuse students, and Peter Bowie, a student at Cornell University. The five, who said they huddled in a pile to stay warm and exercised periodically to ward off hypothermia, walked out shortly after 11 p.m. as search parties were awaiting the go-ahead to re-enter the cave. Horns from several emergency vehicles blared in celebration, and about 100 rescue workers cheered. The students were taken to local hospitals, observed for exposure and released. ``They knew what happened with the water coming in, and they just waited it out like they should have and just walked out,'' said Rick Russo of Albany County Dive Rescue. ``They were more apologetic than anything when they walked out and saw everybody around. ``They kept saying, `We're sorry.' And we said, `It's no problem. You're alive.'''

DOC.HEAD: A Cosmic Show: Japan Watches First Japanese in Space
With AM-Soviet-Space, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan watched with pride Sunday as the first Japanese - and the first journalist of any nationality - traveled into space as a paying passenger aboard a Soviet rocket. Television reporter Toyohiro Akiyama's company, TBS, paid $12 million for his ticket to ride. It is spending about $37 million altogether on the project. In the streets of Tokyo, Japanese clustered around television sets the company had placed at strategic locations to view the fiery launch that took place on steppes of Soviet Central Asia. ``It is like a dream,'' said a middle-aged man, watching. With single-minded determination - and a huge infusion of cash - the company assigned 270 staffers to the story, 170 in the Soviet Union and 100 in Tokyo. Many employees wear badges reading ``Earth we love'' - the project's slogan. With so much money and effort being expended, TBS offered what amounted to saturation coverage. Television viewers saw Akiyama board the craft and heard him say his farewell - a quick ``ittekimasu,'' the standard Japanese phrase on setting out that translates roughly as ``Back later.'' He made his first report two hours after the launch. ``Right now I am flying over the Soviet Union. It is becoming evening. What I can see from the window is darkness. There is a hazy blue earth below, blackish dark blue. ... The earth is blue after all,'' he said. Although much of TBS' coverage of Akiyama's trip will be exclusive, other stations were being supplied with footage for news purposes. The Japan Broadcasting Corp., the national public television network, showed the liftoff on its evening news, but led off its newscast with another story - Japanese hostages' families visiting them in Iraq. But the space flight was a front-page story in the nationwide newspaper Asahi Shimbun, which also ran a page of features inside. Tomoji Oshima, director general of Japan's Science and Technology Agency, called Akiyama ``the first Japanese cosmonaut.'' ``I only pray for his return without any trouble,'' said Izumi Tanaka, the president of TBS. He said Akiyama, a news director, would get a promotion after the mission's end, scheduled Dec. 10. Akiyama, who quit a four-pack-a-day cigarette habit during training for the mission, was asked before liftoff what he looked forward to most on his return. ``I can't wait to have a smoke,'' he said.

``This is a day of great joy. This is a great success and something to be proud of.'' - German Chancellor Helumt Kohl, on his center-right coalition's projected victory in the first free all-German elections since 1932. --- ``The party must fundamentally change if we are still to remain a party in the future.'' - Hubert Kleinert, Greens leader in the outgoing West German parliament, on his party's ouster from the new all-German parliament. --- ``We have another large reason to be happy, and that's the result in Berlin.'' - Helmut Kohl on the conservative victory in the election in reunited Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Democrats Lead in Berlin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE projected results. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Last month's ...'
DOC.TEXT: Berlin voters on Sunday gave conservatives the upper hand in the first all-Berlin elections in 44 years, according to computer projections. The voting marked the final return of Berlin to the city's 4 million people after decades of serving as a pawn of the superpowers. Where Soviet soldiers once faced off against U.S., British and French forces across the Berlin Wall, there is now one united city. Both the ZDF and ARD TV networks projected that the Christian Democratic Union, under former Mayor Eberhard Diepgen, would win 40.1 percent of the vote and take first place. But the party needs support to form a majority in the city government. Diepgen said his party might try to form a ``grand coalition'' with the leftist Social Democrats, who were projected to win 30.3 percent of the vote for second place. ``A difficult negotiating period is in the offing,'' said the ARD television network. Last month's street battles between Berlin police and squatters caused the collapse of the leftist coalition that had governed the city. The local Greens, the environmentalists, had accused Social Democratic Mayor Walter Momper of sending in police units to oust the squatters without consulting the coalition's junior partners. The Christian Democrats, in turn, had played on voters' fears of growing lawlessness. Berlin's results reflected the nationwide voting trends, which gave a resounding victory to the leader of the Christian Democrats, Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``We have another large reason to be happy,'' Kohl told cheering supporters in Bonn. ``And that's the result in Berlin.'' Up until last fall, the authoritarian Communist Party had ruled in East Berlin. Democratically elected governments governed West Berlin under the protection of the victorious World War II allies: France, Britain and the United States. Berlin has been the focus of many of the problems of German unification, which has strained housing and social services. People in former East Berlin are demanding a quick improvement of their dismal standard of living. ``In Berlin, we have to solve a lot of the problems of the growing together of the two countries more quickly than elsewhere,'' Diepgen said. ``There is social tension.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Unions Strike Over Wage Dispute with Government
DOC.TEXT: A general strike on Sunday idled Israel's airports, curtailed radio broadcasts and shut schools, offices and clinics in a dispute over tax increases and the minimum wage. More than 500,000 Israeli government employees heeded the strike call by the Histadrut Labor Federation after the Cabinet added a 5-percent levy to income taxes to finance Soviet immigration. The levy was part of a broader package of austerity measures. Flights carrying immigrants were to be diverted to military airfields, said Israel army radio, which was not affected by the walkout. Workers in essential services heeded government back-to-work orders. Officials of the Jewish Agency, which sees to bringing the immigrants to Israel, stayed on the job saying they did not want to add to the newcomers' difficulties. Originally the strike was supposed to last 24 hours. But after overnight negotiations broke down in disagreement Sunday morning, union leaders said it would continue until a settlement was reached. The main dispute is a government plan to cut the minimum wage by about 20 percent from $520 a month to $417, and a 20 percent tax on pension savings. ``These are painful issues. The workers cannot be pushed to the wall,'' said Yisrael Kessar, general secretary of the Histadrut, an umbrella organization for most of the nation's workforce. Aryeh Stein, a spokesman for the Clerks' Unions, said the pension taxes in effect meant an additional 5 percent pay cut to wage earners seeking to maintain their pension levels. ``We don't object to the special levy for immigrants, but this should be instead of other taxes and not in addition to them,'' Stein said in an interview. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir urged negotiations to continue through Sunday to resolve the dispute. The Histadrut represents about 1.5 million workers, but those employed in private business were exempted from striking, keeping most banks open and public buses running.

DOC.HEAD: `Porte Aperte' Wins Top European Film Award
DOC.TEXT: The Italian film ``Porte Aperte'' was named European Film of the Year on Sunday during presentations of the Felix awards, the European version of the Oscars. Britain's Kenneth Branagh received the Actor of the Year award for his role in ``Henry V,'' which was named Young European Film of the Year. Carmen Maura was named top actress for her role in the Spanish film ``Ay Carmela.'' ``Porte Aperte,'' a political thriller set in 1930s Italy, was directed by Gianni Amelio and produced by Angelo Rizzoli. The Felix awards were presented in Glasgow, one of its last events as European City of Culture in 1990. Swedish director Ingmar Bergman headed the jury, which included actresses Deborah Kerr and Jeanne Moreau.

DOC.HEAD: Baker: U.S. Won't Attack if Iraq Withdraws From Kuwait, Frees Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James Baker A. III assured Iraq on Sunday the United States will not attack that nation if Saddam Hussein withdraws his troops from Kuwait and frees the Western hostages. Baker, who is preparing to visit Iraq before Jan. 15 for talks on the gulf crisis, made the promise to Saddam, the Iraqi president, while insisting there will be no negotiating on the substance of the U.N. resolutions calling for Iraq to get out of Kuwait. An Iraqi official, hinting that a resolution was possible to the increasingly tense international standoff over Kuwait, said his country was willing to discuss ``all the issues.'' Previously, Saddam has claimed that Kuwait had been annexed as a new province of Iraq. As he left Washington Sunday evening for Brazile, President Bush declined to respond directly to reporters' questions about details of pending talks. ``I'm very pleased with the way it's going, but we'll see,'' was his only response. If Saddam meets the U.N. conditions - withdrawal from Kuwait, freedom for hostages and the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government - then there can be discussions of Iraqi grievances against Kuwait, Baker said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. He said talks should be between Kuwait and Iraq, which claims Kuwait is siphoning oil from an oil field along their common border. Iraq also contends it was denied a viable port on the Persian Gulf when Kuwait was created in 1961. Moreover, Baker said the United States would not launch an attack against Iraq to drie Saddam from power if the U.N. conditions are met. ``There's never been any suggestion that force would be used if the U.N. resolutions were fully complied with,'' Baker said. ``That would give some assurance, it seems to me, that if he complied with the resolutions, his reward for that would not be a military attack by the United States,'' Baker said. Iraq on Saturday said it was willing to receive Baker as long as the talks were tied with a resolution of Israel's occupation of Arab lands. But Baker rejected that demand. Baker called the issues ``two entirely different questions and we're not here to link them.'' The U.N. Security Council passed a resolution last week setting a Jan. 15 deadline for the use of force against Iraq if no Saddam doesn't withdraw from Kuwait, and Baker, along with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, on Sunday elaborated on Bush's efforts to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Aside from offering to send Baker to Baghdad, Bush said Friday he would ask Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington next week for talks on the gulf. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas suggested Sunday that congressional leaders also go to Iraq to show support for Bush's efforts. Baker said officials were discussing arrangements for the Baghdad and Washington meetings, ``assuming that the meetings are going to take place.'' Bush's diplomatic gesture followed a week of hearings on Capitol Hill during which several former high-ranking military officers urged the administration to show restraint and give economic sanctions against Iraq more time to work. The hearings resume Monday with testimony by the administration. But Baker said there was an ``excellent chance'' Saddam would withdraw from Kuwait once he understands the depth of opposition to him. A U.S.-led multinational force has arrayed more than 350,000 troops against Saddam in the Persian Gulf. U.S. forces, now numbering more than 240,000, are expected to swell to around 400,000 by next month. Abdul Amir Anbari, the Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations, was asked if his country was prepared to talk about withdrawing from Kuwait. ``We would be willing to talk about all the issues that exist in the region,'' he said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. ``Our president made it quite clear ... that there is no exception and we make no reservation and no condition,'' he said when pressed on the issue. Some American officials have questioned whether the Middle East will ever be safe as long as Saddam remains in power, possesses chemical weapons and is encouraging a nuclear program. Cheney, on the ABC, said the ``overall focus'' of U.S. policy is ``the long-term proposition if Saddam Hussein is not stopped. It's the prospect of having a man who has acquired an enormous force,'' he said. In August, Bush said ``some countries around the world'' hope Saddam would be overthrown by his own people. And he has said that Iraq's nuclear program is a threat. While the United States remains concerned about Saddam's weapons, Baker said ``We would have to find a way to address those issues'' in the aftermath of a resolution of the Kuwaiti crisis. The three U.S. officials raised doubts about the sanctions against Iraq, which Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has encouraged. ``I want to see sanctions work,'' Kennedy said on NBC. ``They are effective. ... I believe we can avoid war and I believe it is important we do avoid war.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Chief Enters Capital; Report Ex-President Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for 14-15 pvs bgng ```Nothing confirms...' to UPDATE with Libyan denunciation of Habre; pickup 16th pvs `About 1,000...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Idriss Deby entered the capital in triumph Sunday and vowed to establish a new government. Conflicting reports emerged over the fate of deposed President Hissene Habre. A Libyan news agency said Habre was killed near the Sudanese border, but diplomats and other sources said Habre and his family flew in a military plane to Cameroon, west of Chad, before dawn Saturday. Neither report could be independently verified. Deby, who helped Habre lead a coup in 1982, arrived in N'Djamena in a black Mercedes, escorted by all-terrain vehicles. He refused to recognize the remnants of Habre's government as the country's legitimate authority, but declared his Patriotic Salvation Movement would institute a democracy. There were no immediate reports of deaths in the takeover, but the French relief agency Doctors Without Borders said it treated 120 people hurt in rioting Saturday. ``My worry is not to be president of the republic,'' said Deby, who served as Habre's chief military adviser from 1982 to 1989. ``This country must become democratic, pluralist. The moment has come to lay down our arms.'' Deby did not rule out being president, but said the decision would rest with his party. He said he wants to meet with Alingue Bawayeu, president of Chad's National Assembly and the highest-ranking politician left in the capital. Deby also urged reconciliation with Goukouni Oueddei, the president he and Habre toppled in 1982. Oueddei is exiled in Libya. On Sunday, Deby met French Ambassador Francois-Xavier Gendreau. The ambassador, however, declined to say whether he tried to persuade Deby to negotiate with Bawayeu. Last year, Habre accused Deby of plotting a coup, and Deby fled to Sudan and organized a rebel movement against his onetime ally. The official Libyan news agency JANA said Habre and several aides had been killed between Tine and Oum Chalouba in eastern Chad, the site of heavy fighting between government soldiers and rebel fighters last week. ``The reports by news media on the escape of Habre with his family on board an aircraft to a neighboring country were not true,'' said JANA, monitored in Rome. The news agency cited no sources, and did not say when Habre had been killed. It provided no further details. But a Patriotic Salvation Movement communique claimed Habre had sought refuge in Maroua, Cameroon, about 185 miles south of N'Djamena. ``Nothing confirms that he died in any fighting,'' French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said in Paris during a televised interview. ``I even have information to the contrary.'' Diplomatic sources also said most of Habre's Cabinet ministers left the capital by vehicle. Though the rebels have been armed by Libya in the past, it is unclear how much help they have received recently from Tripoli. Libya has denied any involvement in the rebel's recent offensive. In its dispatches Sunday, however, the Libyan news agency JANA called Habre a ``brigand'' and hailed the victory of the rebels. ``Habre was an obstacle in the way of national reconciliation between Chadians and an obstacle to good neighborliness and the bonds of history and common suffering between Libyans and Chadians,'' JANA said in the commentary. About 1,000 civilians cheered Deby as his Mercedes-led motorcade pulled into the Place des Martyrs, the central square in the city of 400,000 people. Others waved and cried out from the streets. The capital was calm after being pillaged Saturday by looters and army deserters. Deby's second-in-command, Bada Maldom, arrived at the head of an army of 200 men earlier Sunday. He held several hours of talks with Bawayeu at a hotel before Deby arrived. No details of the talks were disclosed, but they were presumed to concern a handover of power. Under Chad's constitution, Bawayeu leads the country in the president's absence. The rebels, meanwhile, spread throughout the city, taking control of public buildings and key intersections. ``They've moved in, and they're beginning to take over key points around the city,'' a U.S. Embassy official said on condition of anonymity. ``There's an effort to exert public order.'' Three companies of Foreign Legion soldiers landed in N'Djamena on Sunday, reinforcing France's total troop strength in its former colony to 1,800 men. This North African country has about 5.2 million people. Before the arrival of the bulk of Deby's rebels Sunday, the Legionnaires appeared the sole sign of authority. Maldom asked French commanders permission before entering the city. On Saturday, the Legionnaires organized Chad government troops - led by officers sympathetic to Deby - to impose an overnight curfew and disarm looters. Most looters were renegade soldiers or civilians who had picked up weapons thrown down by thousands of army deserters Saturday. France has deployed soldiers in Chad under a defense treaty. They have taken no part in the fighting, which Paris views as a Chadian affair. The Legionnaires organized the evacuation of 948 foreigners to Paris on two flights Sunday. Most of the evacuees were French nationals, but about 50 American dependents were on the flights. The passengers, mostly women and children, did not report ill treatment at the hands of rebels or soldiers, U.S. Embassy officials in Paris said. The evacuation was voluntary. Deby, 38, a brilliant military tactician, broke the morale of government troops after three weeks of victories in eastern Chad. The biggest win was on Thursday when the rebels captured Abeche, a town of 30,000 people 500 miles east of N'Djamena. A day later, they routed government soldiers making a last stand at nearby Oum Hadjer. JANA reported Sunday that Habre had requested U.S. military intervention to save his crumbling government. The U.S. Embassy official said she was unaware of any such request. On Saturday, thousands of people streamed west across the Chari River to Cameroon. Cameroon closed its border with Chad early Sunday. Habre contended the rebels were backed by Libya, which occupied two-thirds of Chad in 1980. The Libyans withdrew in November 1981 but made incursions from the north in August 1983. In 1986, Libya moved further into northern Chad. Deby masterminded a series of lightning attacks the following year that drove the Libyans from the area.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Astronauts Finally in Orbit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `Scientists still ...' to UPDATE with details on initial scientific goals.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CSB5,7
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts, thrilled to finally be orbiting Earth, activated telescopes inside the space shuttle Sunday for more than a week of probing galaxies, quasars and other hot, turbulent objects. The shuttle roared to life at 1:49 a.m. EST Sunday and streaked through a moonlit sky after six months of trying to get off the ground. Three hours later, the seven-man crew began the daylong process of getting the $150 million Astro observatory ready for operation. ``It's like an early Christmas present,'' NASA launch director Bob Sieck said at a post-launch news conference. ``It's been a goal all year ... to get Astro and Columbia on orbit. You could say it took all year to get there, but we're there and we're sure happy about it.'' It was the fifth launch attempt for the mission, first scheduled for 1986 but postponed by the Challenger accident. Fuel leaks halted three countdowns, including the first one in May, and telescope problems ended another. Thick clouds on Sunday threatened to cause yet another delay. The Air Force, which is responsible for range safety, dispatched a helicopter to assure visibility would be sufficient. That check postponed liftoff 21 minutes. Less than 1{ hours after Columbia lifted off, a Soviet rocket hurtled into orbit with two cosmonauts and a Japanese television journalist who will join two other men at space station Mir. Twelve people consequently are now in space, the most at one time, and the Americans are hoping to communicate with their Soviet and Japanese counterparts by ham radio during the mission. Scientists who have been working for years on the Astro project said they could hardly believe it when Columbia finally took off. ``We were so used to not getting it off, the idea that it's actually been launched and it's up there orbiting the Earth is amazing,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator for one of the telescopes. ``We're working minor problems and we're delighted to be working them after 11 years, believe me,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. The first difficulty involved the instrument pointing system for the three ultraviolet telescopes. The system's star trackers failed to work properly in a stowed position, but appeared to operate well after being elevated in the cargo bay, said mission manager Jack Jones. Later in the day, one of the three trackers had trouble detecting dim stars and was being readjusted to use brighter objects for calibration purposes. The pointing system was used only once before, for solar observations in 1985. Numerous problems were encountered during that mission, known as Spacelab-2. ``I had visions of Spacelab-2 dancing in my head,'' astronaut-astronomer Robert Parker told Mission Control. There were some telescope problems later, most of which were resolved quickly, and a computer terminal in the flight deck was turned off after Columbia commander Vance Brand smelled something burning. The computer is believed to have overheated. Scientists still hoped to make their first scientific observation by early Monday. Among the early targets are Capella, a nearby star in the constellation Auriga with an ultraviolet-oozing corona and a supernova remnant in the constellation Vela that is considered a bright X-ray source. Columbia's seven astronauts are splitting 12-hour shifts during the 10-day mission, the first shuttle trip in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. Parker and the three other astronomers on board will operate the ultraviolet telescopes round-the-clock. The X-ray telescope will be managed by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. The observatory will focus on about 240 high-energy objects in space - such as quasars, a supernova and even a comet - as Columbia orbits 218 miles high. Ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from such objects cannot penetrate Earth's atmosphere and thus are invisible from the ground. Scientists expect to improve their understanding of the so-called invisible universe by measuring ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. In addition to stars and galaxies, Astro will examine Jupiter as well as Comet Levy, which is moving rapidly out of the solar system. After a year of frustrations - two leaky shuttles, a flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope, overhauled space station designs - the astronomy mission is helping NASA finish the year on an upswing. It is the third shuttle flight in as many months, a pace not seen since 1985. The Soviet rocket - which also launched a Soviet effort to commercialize its space program - lifted off from the remote Central Asian steppes of Kazakhstan. Journalist Toyohiro Akiyama, 48, joined Soviet cosmonauts Viktor Afanasyev and Musa Manarov in the Soyuz TM-11 space capsule. Akiyama was a passenger under a $12 million contract between the Soviet Union and Japan's biggest private television company, TBS. Akiyama, a TBS news director who quit a four-pack-a-day cigarette habit during the training, was asked before liftoff what he looked forward to most on his return from the first trip into space by a Japanese citizen. ``I can't wait to have a smoke,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ali Lands in Jordan With Former Hostages
LaserPhotos AMM2-3
DOC.TEXT: Boxing great Muhammad Ali accompanied 15 Americans out of Iraq on Sunday, and a spokesman said Ali plans to return to Baghdad later this month to seek freedom for others. Two Canadians and six British employees of the U.S. Bechtel Corp. were also on the Iraqi Airways flight from the Iraqi capital. The Canadians' freedom was secured by a Canadian parliamentary team, and the Britons said they did not know who arranged their release. Airport officials in Baghdad said 25 Belgians flew to Brussels on Sunday in a Belgian airliner that had brought medicine to Iraq. A Belgian parliamentary delegation also left with the freed hostages, the official Iraq News Agency said. The Westerners were the latest to be freed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who has prevented thousands of foreigners from leaving Iraq. Some have been held as ``human shields'' at strategic sites to deter attack by the multinational force in the Persain Gulf. All Americans who flew out with Ali were held at strategic sites in Iraq. Some had first been in hiding in Kuwait for several weeks. Ali, who has Parkinson's disease that hinders his speech, said nothing as he moved through the crowd of journalists. He met with Saddam last week. ``We are concerned about all other Americans that are yet in Iraq who would like to come home for Christmas,'' said Arthur Morrison, a spokesman for the former heavyweight boxing champion. ``We will go back to Iraq for Christmas on behalf of American families.'' Morrison said Ali plans to return to Baghdad on Dec. 24. Saddam has proposed releasing all foreigners between Dec. 25 and March 25 if President Bush pledges not to attack. All the Americans with Ali appeared to be in good health. ``We were treated very well by the Iraqis at our camp,'' said Ralph Leidholdt of Lakewood, Colo., who said he was held at an ammunition factory northwest of Baghdad along with other Westerners but no Americans. Lakewood said spent 73 days as a hostage and 50 days hiding in Kuwait. Sergio Coletta, of Moss Point, Miss., an employee of the American Bureau of Shipping in Kuwait at the time of the Aug. 2 invasion, expressed concern over ``the many other Americans still hiding in Kuwait.'' Coletta said he was held at an industrial site south of Baghdad. ``It is fantastic to be free,'' he said. ``But there are hundreds of others left behind, and I hope that they could also be free and leave for home.'' The two Canadians were Bob McKen, 31, of Edmonton; and Tom Wolf, 30, of Rocky Mountainhouse, Alberta. Their freedom was secured by three Parliament members who visited Iraq last week. The six Britons who arrived Sunday identified themselves as Frank Bennon of Stockport, Bob Fenton of London, Eddie Gore of Manchester, Marl Treen of Surrey, Alex Barran of Scotland, and John Brown of Gravesend. All six were working at a site near Kirkuk in northern Iraq. Fenton said the group was not held as human shields. He said the group found the Iraqi people ``anxious to avoid war.'' The travel schedule of the American group was not immediately known, but U.S. Embassy officials said the former hostages would leave Amman on Monday for Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Besets Daily News Strike
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News strike again was visited by violence Sunday when pickets threw firecrackers and grew rowdy and a striker assaulted a newspaper hawker, resulting in arrests, police said. Police also charged two News replacement drivers with illegal gun possession and said they found an unused pipe bomb near a News printing plant. The unlit, 6-inch pipe bomb was found near a truck lot at the News' Brooklyn plant. Nearby were two unexploded, M-80 firecrackers taped to boxes of nails. Police had gone there to investigate some explosions, apparently caused by firecrackers, a police spokesman said. The News said that 200 strikers were throwing cherry bombs and M-80 firecrackers early Sunday. The firecrackers were tossed into a secluded area, police said, and no one was arrested for that. But police spokesman Sgt. Peter Sweeney said one man was subsequently arrested for striking a police officer with a bottle and four pickets were arrested for disorderly conduct because they were ``loud and boisterous.'' In an unrelated incident, police said two News replacement drivers were charged with weapon possession after a loaded .25-caliber pistol was found in the front seat of their truck early Sunday. Police discovered the weapon when summoned to an accident scene. ``The danger our drivers face on the streets is real as the union-perpetrated violence continues,'' News spokesman John Sloan said. ``But the Daily News does not condone the possession of weapons or the use of force.'' In another incident Sunday morning, a striker was arrested after a hawker was attacked at a Manhattan street corner, police said. Sweeney, the police spokesman, said a truck was dropping off papers when News hawkers were set upon by three people. One assailant sprayed an unknown substance into a hawker's face. A News pressman with 10 years on the job was arrested as a result. The hawker was treated at the scene. The strike by about 2,300 of the News' 3,500 employees began Oct. 25. The paper has printed every day since, though distribution has been a problem. Street hawkers were hired after many newsstands refused to carry the paper. During the strike weekday circulation has dropped from 1.06 million to a little more than 500,000, the News said.

DOC.HEAD: Incomplete Election Results Show Majority for Mubarak's Party
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak's governing party dominated parliamentary elections, but more than 60 percent of the races are headed for a runoff, according to partial results released Sunday. The Thursday elections were boycotted by the major opposition parties to protest allegations the government rigs the votes in its favor. The election was also marred by several clashes between police and voters. At least four people were killed and dozens injured, newspapers and police reported. The announcement of the complete results were delayed because ballot counting in the Nile delta town of Toukh was not finished. The government's daily al-Ahram newspaper reported Sunday that Mubarak's National Deocratic Party won 144 seats in the 454-member People's Assembly, or parliament. Independents won 23 seats and the small leftist National Unionist Progressive Party took one seat. Mubarak will appoint 10 parliamentarians before the legislative body holds its first meeting. Runoffs have been announced for the rest of the seats, 62 percent of parliament. Mubarak's party, which has held majorities of more than 75 percent in the three parliaments since he became president in 1981, is expected to maintain its power in the assembly following the runoff elections. Al-Ahram said there was a 44.71 percent voter turnout. Many Egyptians do not bother to vote because they see the parliament as a rubber stamp of the government's policies. In the Mediterranean city of Damietta, a security source said that at least three people died and more than 41 were wounded Thursday in a clash between police and supporters of an independent candidate who lost. The daily al-Wafd newspaper, linked to the right-of-center New Wafd opposition party that boycotted the elections, reported Sunday there were renewed clashes in the Damietta area which left a 3-year-old boy dead and 30 people wounded. There were also several other incidents that left about 30 people injured.
